question: When a person is compelled to attend an interview under section 206, what notice must be given before the interview, and what grounds are expressly not a reasonable excuse for refusing to answer questions or provide information/documents under the related requirements?
gold_answer: A person who is required to attend an interview must first be given written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions at that interview. [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] Once a requirement to answer questions (and, where applicable, to permit inspection/copying or to give/produce information or a Document) is made under sections 201, 203, or 206(1)(a), (b), (c) and (e), the person cannot treat certain concerns as a “reasonable excuse” for refusing or failing to comply. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab] In particular, the person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer questions on the basis that the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence, with the confidentiality point being expressly subject to section 209(6). [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] The same types of grounds—tending to incriminate the person or revealing a communication made in confidence (again subject to section 209(6))—are also stated not to be a reasonable excuse for refusing or failing to permit inspection/copying of information or a Document, or to give/produce (or procure the giving/production of) information or a Document, when those obligations arise under the specified sections. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: For a decision that may adversely affect a person’s rights, liabilities, or interests, when is it eligible to be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and how do the exclusions and examples in FSMR (including operational decisions and certain decisions outside the Part 21 procedure such as exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers) interact with the rule that covers decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator?
gold_answer: A person may refer to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review a decision that meets the adverse-effect threshold, but the availability of referral must be read together with the FSMR carve-out for operational decisions and the FSMR indication that some additional categories of decisions are also referable even though they are not within the Part 21 procedure. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] The threshold condition is that the decision may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests, and the referral is made by that affected person. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] Within that scope, FSMR states that all of our decisions meeting that threshold may be referred, except for operational decisions, which are excluded from referral. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] In addition, FSMR explains that certain other decisions—specifically identified as not being subject to the Part 21 procedure—may still be referred for a full merits review, with the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers given as an example. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] Accordingly, for decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator that meet the adverse-effect threshold, referral is available unless the decision is operational, and FSMR also contemplates referral for specified non‑Part 21 decisions such as Own‑Initiative Powers. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: When the Regulator is considering disqualifying an auditor or actuary for a contravention, how should it determine both whether to disqualify and the scope of the disqualification (e.g., across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or a particular class), and what case-specific factors must be weighed?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has contravened these Regulations, it has discretion to disqualify that person from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or for a particular class of them; the scope decision is therefore part of the same assessment as whether to disqualify at all. [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] In deciding whether to exercise the disqualification power and what the scope of any disqualification will be, the Regulator must evaluate all the circumstances of the case, rather than relying on a single trigger. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The factors to be weighed include the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects, and whether the contravention (or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has resulted in or is likely to result in customer loss, reputational damage to the ADGM, or increased financial-crime risk involving a firm, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The Regulator should also consider remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, any professional-body disciplinary action (and whether it adequately addresses the contravention), and the auditor’s or actuary’s prior compliance record including relevant prior sanctions. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: If a Reporting Entity asks the Listing Authority for a Trading Halt or Suspension because it needs time to get a Disclosure of Inside Information ready, what details does it usually have to explain, and what situations (like lost confidentiality or the RIE being open/closed) can make a Trading Halt or Suspension necessary?
gold_answer: When a Reporting Entity asks the Listing Authority for a Trading Halt or Suspension to create time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information, the Listing Authority typically requires a clear explanation of the request and then makes its own judgment on whether the halt/suspension is warranted. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] The Reporting Entity will usually be asked to describe: what the Inside Information is about, why it needs the Trading Halt or Suspension, what event is expected to end the halt/suspension, and what it plans to disclose (scope) and when it expects to release that Disclosure. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] A Trading Halt or Suspension may be necessary to manage Disclosure issues in several situations, including where there are signs the Inside Information is no longer confidential before Disclosure and it is affecting price (or, if the RIE is not yet open, is likely to affect price when the RIE opens). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] It can also be necessary if the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity to correct or prevent a false market, or if the Inside Information is especially significant and likely to cause a major price movement (for example, a significant capital raising, the Board resolving to appoint an administrator, or approval of a one-off contract that substantially changes the Listed Entity’s scale and activities). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] The RIE’s trading status is part of the necessity analysis: if trading is open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose immediately, or if trading is closed and it cannot disclose before the RIE opens, that supports using a Trading Halt or Suspension. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9]
target_text:
IMMEDIATELY
Use of a Trading Halt or Suspension to manage Disclosure issues
A Trading Halt or Suspension may, however, be necessary in the following circumstances:

a)	there are indications that the Inside Information has lost its confidentiality ahead of a Disclosure (see Rule 7.2.2(2)), and it is having, or (where the RIE upon which the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading is not yet open for trading) is likely to have, when the RIE opens for trading, a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities;

b)	the Reporting Entity has been asked by the Listing Authority to correct or prevent a false market;  or

c)	the information is particularly significant Inside Information and likely to cause a significant movement in the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities (for example, Inside Information relating to a significant capital raising, the Board of the Listed Entity resolving to appoint an administrator, or that the Listed Entity is to win approval for a one-off contract that will substantially change the scale and activities of the Listed Entity);

and in circumstances where the RIE’s market is:

d)	open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity is not in a position to make the Disclosure immediately; or

e)	not open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity will not be in a position to make the Disclosure before the RIE opens for trading.

question: How should a PFP Operator align its six-year record-retention duties with its obligation to publish due-diligence-related information to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform, particularly where the due diligence is undertaken under Rule 18.4.1?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must both (i) keep specified records for at least six years and (ii) publish specified due-diligence information for PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform it operates; the two obligations should be implemented together so the published due-diligence description is supportable by retained evidence. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] The record-keeping duty applies to the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1, as well as to all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 and documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Separately, the publication duty includes making available to PFP Clients the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] Practically, the PFP Operator should retain, for the six-year minimum, the underlying due-diligence work and related communications so it can substantiate the published methodology/limitations and keep a consistent compliance trail across what is disclosed/published and what is documented. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count financial collateral, what are the two allowed methods it can use, and if it picks the FCCA method, what kinds of collateral count (including the extra rules for fund Units)?
gold_answer: To recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, an Authorised Person is required to use one of two methods: the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA). [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] Choosing FCCA matters because it determines what can be treated as eligible financial Collateral under that approach. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] Under FCCA, eligible financial Collateral includes any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5, plus any equity Security (and this explicitly includes a convertible bond) as long as it is traded on a regulated exchange. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] FCCA also allows Units in a Collective Investment Fund, but only where the Fund invests in the regulated-exchange-traded equity Securities described above and two conditions are satisfied: the Unit price is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in the FCCA rule and in Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] This FCCA eligibility list sits alongside the overarching requirement that the Authorised Person must use either FCSA (adopting the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 for collateral composition) or FCCA (adopting the treatment under Rule 4.13.6) when recognising eligible financial Collateral. [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets and therefore must seek FSRA approval for both asset types, how should the firm assess whether fees for the two categories could be charged cumulatively, and what discretion does the Regulator have to reduce, waive, or refund fees (including supplementary or late payment fees) in that context?
gold_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person plans to conduct a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets as well as Virtual Assets, it must obtain FSRA approval to carry on the Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] In assessing whether fees for the conventional and Virtual Asset-related activities will be cumulative, the firm should treat non-cumulative outcomes as dependent on the FSRA’s exercise of discretion to reduce or waive a fee, rather than as an automatic entitlement. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] The Regulator’s discretion is broad: it may, at any time, reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee, and this expressly includes supplementary or late payment fees, where it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Practically, this means the firm should (i) identify the fee exposure associated with seeking approval for both asset types, and (ii) consider whether there is a case-specific basis to request relief on fairness and reasonableness grounds, recognizing that the decision rests with the Regulator. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] The FSRA also recommends raising fee questions with it as early as practicable to clarify expectations and timing around any potential discretionary relief. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689]
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Noting the above paragraph, if an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets (e.g. securities or derivatives) in addition to Virtual Assets, as noted in paragraphs 20 to 21, it will need to seek approval from the FSRA to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types (conventional and Virtual Asset).  The fees attributable to that Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities (conventional and Virtual Asset-related), may not be cumulative should the FSRA apply its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, under FEES 1.2.8 subject to the considerations set out in paragraph 187 below).  The FSRA recommends that Applicants discuss any questions relating to FEES with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Relief from Payment
The Regulator may at any time reduce, waive or refund all or part of any fee including any supplementary or late payment fee if it considers that, in the circumstances of a particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so.

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCCA and takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what number should they use instead of E when working out the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount, and how do they calculate it (including what haircuts and values go into the formula)?
gold_answer: They must use E* instead of E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the CR Exposure, because the transaction is an SFT with eligible financial Collateral, the FCCA is used, and there is no qualifying bilateral Netting agreement. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] E* is the exposure value after risk mitigation and must be calculated using the FCCA haircut method formula for collateralised transactions that are not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement (and, here, the transaction is not described as an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction). [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] The calculation is: E* = max{0, [E(1+HE) − C(1−HC−HFX)]}. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] In that formula, E is the fair value of the Exposure (calculated under the referenced section), C is the fair value of the eligible financial Collateral received, HE is the haircut for the Exposure, HC is the haircut for the Collateral (or a weighted sum if the Collateral is a basket of assets), and HFX is the haircut for any currency mismatch between the Collateral and the Exposure. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] Once E* is computed, it is substituted for E in the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount calculation for that CR Exposure. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: Where a Payment Service Provider offers a Single Payment Service Contract that is also intended to sit within a Framework Contract, what pre-contract information must be provided to the Payment Service User before they are bound, and how should that be aligned with the Framework Contract’s required disclosures on execution timing, identifiers, and charges (including exchange-rate details where relevant)?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must ensure the Payment Service User receives specified pre-contract information for the Single Payment Service Contract before the Payment Service User becomes bound, and that this pre-contract package is consistent with the corresponding Framework Contract disclosures on the same topics. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Before the Payment Service User is bound, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available (for example via a draft Single Payment Service Contract or draft Payment Order) the identifier or other information the Payment Service User must supply for proper initiation/execution, the maximum execution time, the charges (and breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] In parallel, the Framework Contract must include, among other items, the identifier information for initiating/executing Payment Orders, the maximum execution time for the Payment Services, and detailed charges payable (including charges connected to information being provided/made available and a breakdown where applicable). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Where exchange rates are relevant, the Framework Contract must also include the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, the method for calculating the relevant date for determining them. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If someone managing a holding lock under Rule 9.6.9 wants the Regulator to let Restricted Securities holders take part in a Takeover (by accepting an offer or transferring/cancelling Securities), what does the offer have to cover, what level of acceptance is needed from non-Restricted Securities holders, and when do the parties have to agree in writing to put the holding lock back on?
gold_answer: A party managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 can ask the Regulator to allow the holding lock to be released so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] The Regulator will only provide consent if the applicable conditions are met for the way the Takeover is being done. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover involves an offer for Securities, the offer must be for all of the Ordinary Securities, or (if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities) for all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] Also, at least half of the holders of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities (and that the offer relates to) must have accepted the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed for each Security the offeror does not buy. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover is done by a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity comes up with new material estimates for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves that it has never disclosed before, how fast does it need to disclose them, and what details must it include about licences, the new data, and what changed compared with earlier disclosures?
gold_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must disclose the new material estimates immediately when they have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When it makes that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also include enough detail to show what the estimates relate to and why they changed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] The disclosure needs to include, at a minimum: - The types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - A clear explanation of the new data and information. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - An explanation of how the new data and information affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Resources (which includes Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Any changes or additions to what it previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves, using the listed prior-disclosure groupings. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] So the rule is both “disclose right away” and “include the specified supporting explanations and updates to earlier information.” [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]
target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must immediately disclose any new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed.

question: When considering an Application for Listing, what actions may the Regulator take regarding admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does the authority under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR relate to the circumstance-based power described in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: The Regulator has power to manage outcomes at the listing stage by either declining the Application for Listing or controlling the terms on which Securities are admitted to the Official List through conditions or restrictions, including later changing or removing those conditions or restrictions. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] In addition, section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR specifically supports the Regulator’s ability to impose conditions or restrictions on admission to the Official List and to vary or withdraw them, which aligns with (and is reflected in) the same set of actions described for admission decisions in the listing context. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The circumstance-based framing in the listing provision means these actions (refusal, or the imposition/variation/withdrawal of conditions or restrictions) are exercisable in the circumstances identified in subsection (2), rather than as an unqualified discretion. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Practically, this links the FSMR section 52(1)(b) authority over admission conditions to the listing decision pathway that also includes the option to refuse the Application for Listing, with both sets of actions operating within the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: If someone is on the list in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and a buyer of the Securities loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person do (and by when) to avoid liability—especially if the problem is about an Expert’s competence or consent?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, that person can have to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person avoids incurring liability for the loss if, before the Securities were acquired, a correction is published in a way meant to bring it to the attention of people likely to buy those Securities. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] If the issue is a statement attributed to an Expert, the same timing and publication approach can be used by publishing that the Expert was not competent or did not consent to having the attributed statement included in the Prospectus. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] A second route is available: the person can avoid liability if they took all steps that were reasonable to secure that publication and reasonably believed it had happened before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] In short, the compensation risk tied to misleading statements or required omissions is addressed by timely publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]
source_text:
Without prejudice to (2) and (3), a Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss in respect of any Securities caused by any statement or omission as is mentioned in that Article if:
(a)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person, a correction or, where the statement was such as is mentioned in (2)(c), the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to the inclusion of the statement attributed to that Expert in the Prospectus had been published in a manner designed to bring to the attention of Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question; or
(b)	he took all such steps as it was reasonable for him to take to secure such publication and believed on reasonable grounds that such a publication had taken place before the Securities were acquired.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers taken under section 206(1)(a) for use in criminal proceedings against that same person, how do the Regulator’s notification practice and the Investigator’s disclosure prohibition operate together, including the consent pathway and the law/court-order exception?
gold_answer: In this scenario, disclosure to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings against the person is generally blocked unless a specific condition is met, and the person is typically given a chance to respond before disclosure occurs. The Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the person’s statement (i.e., answers to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement) to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator must disclose due to law or a court order. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives such a request from a law enforcement agency, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned so the person has an opportunity either to consent to the disclosure or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] This notification practice aligns with the consent-based disclosure route described for the Investigator, because the person’s consent is one of the two stated gateways for disclosure. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] However, the notification is not expected where disclosure is compelled: the Regulator may be required by law or court order to disclose the statement, and in that case the Regulator may disclose without following the general notification approach. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The same law/court-order compulsion is also an express exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]
source_text: If the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for a person's answers in an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will, in accordance with section 207(2) of the FSMR, generally notify the person concerned of such request (so that the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request), unless the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_text:
The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless—
(a)	the person consents to the disclosure; or
(b)	the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the requirement to perform accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts at least every calendar month be reflected in the contents of the Resolution Pack, and what specific reconciliation-related record must be included?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must both (i) run accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts on a schedule that is as frequent as needed but no less than monthly, and (ii) ensure the Resolution Pack contains evidence of those reconciliations in the form of the most recent reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The monthly reconciliation obligation is framed as a systems-and-controls requirement aimed at ensuring reconciliations are accurate and performed at least every calendar month, so the firm should operate controls that reliably produce reconciliation outputs on that cadence (or more often where necessary). [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To align the Resolution Pack with that operational requirement, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, which provides a concrete, current record demonstrating that reconciliation activity is being performed and documented. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the firm should be able to point from its monthly (or more frequent) reconciliation process for Client Accounts to the latest completed reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments that are filed in the Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information to a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator to facilitate the carrying out of a Public Function, what discretion does the Regulator have to impose conditions on the requesting authority and restrict how the information may be used, and how does that interact with the permitted disclosure pathway described?
gold_answer: The Regulator may disclose Confidential Information to a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator where the disclosure is for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of a Public Function and is made to one of the listed recipient categories, including a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] In that scenario, the Regulator also has discretion, when disclosing Confidential Information under section 199(1), to require the requesting authority to comply with conditions or to agree to limits on the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] Practically, this means the Regulator can both (i) rely on the Public Function facilitation basis and the specified recipient category to make the disclosure, and (ii) attach use-restrictions or other conditions directed at the requesting authority as part of the disclosure process. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] The scope of any conditions or restrictions is determined by what the Regulator considers appropriate, rather than being fixed by the recipient category itself. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f]
source_text: As set out in paragraphs 4.1.3 and 4.1.4 above, in disclosing any Confidential Information under section 199(1), the Regulator may require the requesting authority to comply with certain conditions or agree to restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 and treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, what specific statements and explanatory content must it provide, and how does that disclosure need to connect to the Production Target from which the forecast is derived (including the Rule 11.8.3 information)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 must still provide a complete, investor-understandable explanation of how its forecast is built, even if it treats material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In that scenario, it must (i) identify all material economic assumptions used, and (ii) if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, include an explicit statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where it relies on the relevant guidance, it must also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose enough information—potentially using narrative rather than numbers—to allow investors to understand the methodology used to determine the factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] Separately, the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived and include all information required by Rule 11.8.3 for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The commercially sensitive treatment does not remove the need to provide sufficient methodological context for investors, including the basis for Ore Reserves estimates. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it:

a)	must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive;

b)	should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and

c)	must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: If the Investigator is running an investigation, who can be told to come to an interview and answer questions, and what else can the Investigator ask for in the same written notice (including when and where things must happen)?
gold_answer: In an investigation, the Investigator can require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of that investigation. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] The Investigator can do this by sending a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation, telling them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That same written notice can also require additional cooperation steps, such as producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, providing information, and providing assistance. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] It can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents kept there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Taken together, the investigative interview requirement can be paired with these other notice-based requirements, with the notice setting the relevant specified time/place or the normal-business-hours condition, as applicable. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: If you have precise information that isn’t public and it’s about a Reporting Entity or Issuer, how do you decide whether it counts as “Inside Information” for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, especially when it might move the price of a Related Instrument?
gold_answer: You treat it as “Inside Information” only if it meets the full definition for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, including the part about likely price impact. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] First, the information must be of a Precise nature and not generally available. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Second, it must relate directly or indirectly either to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments, or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Third, you must consider whether making it public would be likely to have a significant effect on price. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] In doing that price test, you do not stop at the main product mentioned: the definition also covers a likely significant effect on the price of Related Instruments (as well as Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, and Accepted Spot Commodities) within the non-Commodity Derivatives scope. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] If any of these elements is missing, the information does not meet the definition. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18]
source_text:
Definition. "Inside Information" is defined in section 95(2) as meaning information of a Precise nature which, in relation to Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities which are not Commodity Derivatives:
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities or on the price of Related Instruments.
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, what fee basis applies to the application, and in what circumstance may the Regulator additionally impose a supplementary fee linked to the destination jurisdiction’s regulatory cooperation arrangements?
gold_answer: For an application by an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM to establish a branch outside ADGM, the applicant must pay an application fee calculated as 50% of the highest application fee in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities it proposes to carry on from that branch. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] In addition to that application-fee basis, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction in which there is not an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] Practically, this means the fee outcome has two components: (i) a mandatory application fee tied to the highest Chapter 3 fee applicable to the Regulated Activities intended to be undertaken from the branch, and (ii) a potential extra charge that depends on whether the destination jurisdiction has adequate regulatory cooperation arrangements in place with the Regulator. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] The supplementary fee is not automatic; it is triggered by the absence of an adequate memorandum of understanding with the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the jurisdiction where the branch would operate. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]
source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
target_text: Where an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, it must pay to the Regulator an application fee equal to 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of these Rules for those Regulated Activities it seeks to undertake from the proposed branch.

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, how does the eligibility condition for recognising CRM interact with the requirement to risk weight a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, including the applicable risk weights by Credit Quality Grade and for unrated exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB only where the MDB is one of the MDBs referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, so the protection provider must fall within that MDB category for CRM recognition to be available. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, where the exposure is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must apply the MDB asset class risk-weighting table (noting it is stated to be subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] In practice, this means you address two linked determinations: (i) whether the protection provider qualifies as an MDB for purposes of recognising CRM effects, and (ii) how the relevant CR Exposure in the MDB asset class is risk weighted under the table. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] Under the table, Credit Quality Grade 1 receives a 0% risk weight; Grades 2 and 3 receive 50%; Grades 4 and 5 receive 100%; Grade 6 receives 150%; and unrated exposures receive 50%. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]
target_text:
Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the MDB asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the MDB asset class
/Table Start
Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	0%	50%	50%	100%	100%	150%	50%
/Table End

question: When the FSRA expects a "substantial additional" regulatory burden or costs/effort in dealing with an application or ongoing supervision, what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do regarding fee implications, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s ability to require a supplementary fee (including in the example of migrating an MTF to become a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: Where a matter creates a “substantial additional” burden for the FSRA/Regulator, the fee outcome can extend beyond standard charges, and the Applicant/Authorised Person should proactively engage early on fee implications. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Specifically, the FSRA indicates it retains the ability to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is placed on it, and it highlights migration of an MTF into a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of such a circumstance. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] In parallel, the Regulator’s supplementary-fee power is framed around situations where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or to expend substantial additional effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or in conducting on-going supervision. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Taken together, the practical compliance step is that, when the Applicant/Authorised Person anticipates a scenario like an MTF migration (or any application/supervision activity likely to drive substantial additional effort), they should discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable, because the Regulator may respond by requiring a supplementary fee reflecting that additional cost/effort. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Pursuant to FEES Rule 1.2.4, the FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees in circumstances where a ‘substantial additional’ regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA. In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional ‘Securities’ Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If the Regulator is looking at an Application for Listing, what can it do (including refusing the application), and how does section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR fit with the rule that these actions are only available in the circumstances in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: For an Application for Listing, the Regulator can choose to refuse the Application for Listing, or it can allow admission of Securities to the Official List but attach conditions or restrictions to that admission. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] If conditions or restrictions are used, the Regulator can also later change them or remove them entirely (vary or withdraw them). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR provides the underlying authority for the admission-related part of this: it expressly allows the Regulator to impose conditions or restrictions on admission of Securities to the Official List and to vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The listing provision adds an important boundary: the Regulator’s ability to refuse the application or to impose/vary/withdraw admission conditions is stated to apply in the circumstances specified in subsection (2). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Taken together, section 52(1)(b) explains the scope of the admission-condition tools, while the listing provision ties both refusal and those tools to the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
gold_answer: If the Regulator forms the view that a relevant name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another product, the Regulator has power to issue a direction under Section 117 of FSMR covering not only a Fund and a Sub-Fund but also a class of Units in a Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] When exercising that power in relation to a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator may require a concrete remedial step: it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The triggering conditions align across both passages: the Regulator’s assessment (including where the name conflicts with another Fund/Sub-Fund name, or is undesirable or misleading) is the basis for intervention. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The scope of what can be assessed for undesirability, misleading character, or conflict is broader in that it expressly includes a class of Units in a Fund in addition to Funds and Sub-Funds. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the Fund Manager as the directed party for Fund/Sub Fund name changes, while recognizing that the Regulator’s naming-direction power extends to class-of-Units naming issues as well. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_text:
Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the required minimum systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and key management be integrated into the broader technology governance expectations on system maintenance/testing and third-party interfaces, so that both sets of requirements are met?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must implement documented systems and controls for Virtual Asset wallets and for private/public keys, and those controls should be embedded within a wider technology governance framework that also addresses system upkeep/testing and third-party service interfaces. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] Practically, this means the wallet and key procedures are not standalone documents; they should be maintained and evolved through disciplined system development practices (such as controlled updates, issue resolution, and regular internal and third-party testing) so the controls remain effective as the architecture changes. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] At a minimum, the wallet procedures should cover lifecycle activities (setup/configuration/deployment/deletion/backup and recovery), access privilege and user management, rule/limit determination with review and updates, and audit/oversight, while key procedures should address generation, exchange, storage, backup, destruction, access management, public key sharing, and re-use where applicable. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Where any wallet or key functionality relies on external providers (e.g., custody tooling, cloud services, or data/service recipients), the Authorised Person should also maintain procedures governing the creation and management of services, interfaces, and channels provided by or to third parties to ensure those dependencies are controlled. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2]

question: When calculating CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), how should an Authorised Person determine whether to use gross long positions or a net long position approach for Trading Book holdings, and what additional method applies where the Trading Book exposure is indirect via index Securities?
gold_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must apply the Trading Book-specific netting methodology described for those holdings, rather than defaulting to a gross-long-only approach for all positions. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] The SOURCE establishes that, for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the deductible amount is calculated on the basis of gross long positions (with a stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15), which creates the baseline calculation concept that must be reconciled with the TARGET’s Trading Book treatment for (g) and (h). [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] In practice under (g) and (h), for holdings in the Trading Book, the holdings must be calculated using the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only where the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] Additionally, where the Trading Book holding is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities included in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
target_text:
CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following:
(a)	the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and
(b)	the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items normally required for material Non-Equivalent Estimates (such as source/date, reliability, and the Competent Person statement), and what specific statement must still be included in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed information otherwise required for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if the later disclosure is structured as a true follow-on to an earlier disclosure that already met those detailed requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting either how the Non-Equivalent Estimates should be relied on/interpreted or the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on that omission pathway, the later disclosure must still carry an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that addresses the same core matters as the required prominent/proximate warning for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: For Derivative transactions (including written credit protection) that are on-balance sheet items, how should the firm determine the exposure measure, and how does that interact with the requirement to calculate exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) unless the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the firm should build the exposure measure by combining two components: (1) the on-balance sheet value determined under IFRS and (2) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] In parallel, the exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) must be calculated in accordance with the SA-CCR section, and this SA-CCR requirement also applies to long settlement transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] The linkage is that, when the Derivative is an on-balance sheet item, the exposure value construction (IFRS on-balance sheet value plus the specified potential future exposure add-on) provides the concrete inputs and method elements the firm uses to operationalize its Derivative exposure calculation, while the SA-CCR section establishes that the firm must calculate EAD under that section for Derivative transactions unless it has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] If the Authorised Person has Regulator permission to use an internal model, the SA-CCR calculation mandate does not apply in the same way for those transactions. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The exposure at default (EAD) of Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions must be calculated in accordance with this Section unless the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model.

question: For purposes of determining the CRW used in the PSIACOMcredit formula for an Islamic Contract, how must an Authorised Person categorise a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days and meets all conditions of the regulatory retail asset class (including the $2 million obligor limit), and at what point in the PSIACOMcredit calculation sequence is that CRW applied?
gold_answer: If the CR Exposure is not past due for more than 90 days and meets all the stated conditions for the regulatory retail asset class—including that the exposure is to an individual/group of individuals or a small business, is in one of the specified product forms, is part of a sufficiently granular pool of similar exposures, and does not exceed $2 million to any obligor or group—then the Authorised Person must categorise it as a regulatory retail asset class exposure. [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f] That categorisation is relevant to PSIACOMcredit because, for each Islamic Contract to which the PSIACOMcredit section applies, the Authorised Person must determine the risk weighting or capital charge appropriate to the contract, which constitutes the CRW for that contract, and then apply the relevant IFR formula to calculate PSIACOMcredit for that contract. [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787] In sequence, the Authorised Person first identifies all applicable Islamic Contracts, then values the underlying investment or asset and applies the required reduction to produce “E,” then determines the CRW (using the exposure’s asset-class treatment, here regulatory retail), and only after that applies the formula in IFR 5.4.7(b) or (c) to compute PSIACOMcredit. [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787] Finally, it sums the PSIACOMcredit across contracts to arrive at the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person. [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to previously disclosed Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it include to rely on the “first time only” application of Rule 11.12.1, and how does that interact with the Competent Person statement elements required in a disclosure containing those items?
gold_answer: To rely on Rule 11.12.1 applying only to the first disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.12.1 and (ii) include a confirmation that the entity is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects what was included previously; for Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves estimates, it must also confirm that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning those estimates still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] In addition, where the later disclosure itself contains Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (or Exploration Targets), it must include a Competent Person statement that the disclosure is based on and fairly represents information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] That statement must also specify, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Finally, it must name the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Together, the cross-reference/confirmation conditions support the “first time only” treatment, while the Competent Person statement elements govern what must be stated in any disclosure that contains the relevant technical content. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When a Listed Entity proposes an issue of Securities that is intended to be made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), what approval mechanics and voting restrictions must be satisfied, and how do those requirements change if there is a material change to the terms after approval but before completion?
gold_answer: For an issue of Securities that is made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), the Listed Entity must structure the process as a Shareholder approval for the proposed Related Party Transaction and obtain prior approval by a majority of the Shareholders before entering into the transaction when the 5% net-assets threshold is met or exceeded. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] In addition, the Related Party must not vote on that Shareholder resolution and must take all reasonable steps to ensure any Related Party Associates also do not vote. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] If, after obtaining Shareholder approval under Rule 9.5.3(1) but before completion of the Related Party Transaction, there is a material change to the terms of the proposed transaction, the Listed Entity must separately comply again with the same Shareholder-approval requirement for that Related Party Transaction (i.e., re-seek approval under Rule 9.5.3(1)). [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] These mechanics apply in the specific context where the securities issuance is being carried out on the basis of approval by holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4]
source_text: An issue of Securities made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction).

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target for an operating mine, in what circumstances is it not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2, and what specific content must still be included in the disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 (including how to handle commercially sensitive material economic assumptions)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) where that forecast financial information is wholly based on (i) Ore Reserves, (ii) a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources, or (iii) a combination of Ore Reserves with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources, provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] Even in that scenario, if the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, the disclosure must include the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, covering all material economic assumptions employed and all other material assumptions utilised. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
