(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to Provide Custody for a Fund (or act as Trustee of an Investment Trust) and is also allowed to Accept Deposits (or manage a PSIAu), what checks decide whether it is Category 3B or Category 1?
gold_answer: To decide between Category 3B and Category 1, the Authorised Person should look at which permissions are treated as the deciding factor for each category and then apply the relevant “not in” checks. Category 1 applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm must also not meet the criteria of Category 5. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] Category 3B applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm must also not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] Because Category 3B expressly excludes firms that meet Category 1, a firm that has the Category 1-type permissions (Accepting Deposits or PSIAu management) would fail the Category 3B exclusion test unless it does not meet Category 1. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] In both categories, the guidance clarifies that the firm may have other Regulated Activities, but the listed permissions are what determine the category outcome. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When a Reporting Entity requests a Trading Halt or Suspension from the Listing Authority to obtain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information, what information will the Listing Authority usually require the Reporting Entity to provide, and in what types of Disclosure-management circumstances might a Trading Halt or Suspension be considered necessary (including how the RIE’s trading status affects that assessment)?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity seeking a Trading Halt or Suspension to gain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information should expect the Listing Authority to require specific contextual details, and the Listing Authority will then decide whether the situation justifies the halt/suspension. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] In practice, the Listing Authority will usually ask the Reporting Entity to outline: the nature of the Inside Information, why the Trading Halt or Suspension is being requested, what event is expected to end it, and the intended scope and timing for releasing the Disclosure. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] Those inputs are assessed against circumstances where a Trading Halt or Suspension may be necessary to manage Disclosure issues, including where confidentiality appears to have been lost ahead of Disclosure and the information is having (or, if the RIE is not yet open, is likely to have when it opens) a significant price effect. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] It may also be necessary if the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity to correct or prevent a false market, or if the Inside Information is particularly significant and likely to move the price materially (with examples such as a significant capital raising, a board decision to appoint an administrator, or winning approval for a one-off contract that substantially changes scale and activities). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] The RIE’s status matters: if the market is open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose immediately, or if the market is not open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose before the RIE opens, that timing constraint supports the need for a halt/suspension. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9]
target_text:
IMMEDIATELY
Use of a Trading Halt or Suspension to manage Disclosure issues
A Trading Halt or Suspension may, however, be necessary in the following circumstances:

a)	there are indications that the Inside Information has lost its confidentiality ahead of a Disclosure (see Rule 7.2.2(2)), and it is having, or (where the RIE upon which the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading is not yet open for trading) is likely to have, when the RIE opens for trading, a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities;

b)	the Reporting Entity has been asked by the Listing Authority to correct or prevent a false market;  or

c)	the information is particularly significant Inside Information and likely to cause a significant movement in the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities (for example, Inside Information relating to a significant capital raising, the Board of the Listed Entity resolving to appoint an administrator, or that the Listed Entity is to win approval for a one-off contract that will substantially change the scale and activities of the Listed Entity);

and in circumstances where the RIE’s market is:

d)	open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity is not in a position to make the Disclosure immediately; or

e)	not open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity will not be in a position to make the Disclosure before the RIE opens for trading.

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business plans to deposit Client Money into a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, what specific written acknowledgment must it obtain from the Third-Party Agent, and how should that acknowledgment be treated within the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack record set?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent before it deposits Client Money into a Client Account established with that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] That acknowledgment must state (i) that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients, and (ii) that the Third-Party Agent has no entitlement to combine the account with any other account or to assert any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off, combination, or counterclaim against Money in the account for amounts owed to it by the Authorised Person. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] From a records and resolution-planning perspective, the Authorised Person must ensure that records relating to Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money are included in its Resolution Pack. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the written acknowledgment obtained as a precondition to depositing Client Money should be retained and organized as part of the Resolution Pack materials covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment for Client Money, alongside the other specified Resolution Pack records (such as master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: Before depositing Client Money in a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent stating that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account, or exercise any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off or combination or counterclaim against Money in that account in respect of any sum owed to it by the Authorised Person.

question: Where a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, when must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s ability to vary or cancel a Financial Services Permission affect that deadline under the framework addressing variation and cancellation on the Regulator’s initiative?
gold_answer: If a FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The default deadline for ceasing that Regulated Activity is the point when its RegLab FSP expires, reflecting the stated two-year validity period for that permission. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] However, that deadline is not fixed solely by expiry: it can be brought forward (or otherwise altered) if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP, because the cessation deadline is also defined as “at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP” in accordance with the referenced mechanism. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] In applying this, the relevant framework is the regime concerning “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission,” specifically where variation or cancellation occurs on the initiative of the Regulator. [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat expiry as the baseline stop date, but also monitor for any Regulator-initiated variation or cancellation that would trigger an earlier (or otherwise revised) cessation point. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]
source_text: Two-year validity period. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab.  The deadline for ceasing the Regulated Activity will be upon the expiry of its RegLab FSP, or at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR.  Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: If an Authorised Person is going to put Client Money into a Client Account with a Third-Party Agent, what does the Third-Party Agent’s written acknowledgment need to say, and does that acknowledgment need to be kept in the Resolution Pack?
gold_answer: Before the Authorised Person deposits Client Money into a Client Account that is established with a Third-Party Agent, it must first get a written acknowledgment from that Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] The acknowledgment has to confirm that the Money in the account is held by the Authorised Person for its Clients, and it must also confirm the Third-Party Agent cannot merge that account with other accounts or use the Money as security or to set off or counterclaim against debts the Authorised Person owes the Third-Party Agent. [#TGT:4b3b6294-0035-4dd7-b254-827c825338b9] Separately, the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack must include records covering Third-Party Agent acknowledgment in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Putting these together, the written acknowledgment you obtain as a condition of depositing Client Money should be retained in a way that allows it to be included within the Resolution Pack record set for Third-Party Agent acknowledgment relating to Client Money, along with the other Resolution Pack items required for Client Money and Client Investments (for example, master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: Before depositing Client Money in a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent stating that all Money standing to the credit of the account is held by the Authorised Person on behalf of its Clients and that the Third-Party Agent is not entitled to combine the account with any other account, or exercise any charge, mortgage, security, lien, right of set-off or combination or counterclaim against Money in that account in respect of any sum owed to it by the Authorised Person.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has an operating mine(s) and its Production Target is built only from Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources (and maybe Indicated Mineral Resources, but Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), does it still need to include the assumptions and proportion breakdown details required for a disclosure made under Rule 11.8.2, even though Rule 11.8.3 does not apply?
gold_answer: Yes. If the Production Target for an operating mine(s) is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources (with Indicated Mineral Resources not being the determining factor in project viability), the Mining Reporting Entity does not have to make its disclosure comply with Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:1d86427d-4a34-4179-bd16-1f64e7ef8560] But when the entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, it still must provide the specific information that Rule 11.8.2 requires about the Production Target. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] That includes disclosing all material economic assumptions used to determine the Production Target, or if those assumptions are commercially sensitive, stating that and explaining the methodology used to determine them, and also disclosing all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If forecast commodity prices were used, it must also say they were reached on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In addition, it must show the proportions of the Production Target that are based on the listed categories, including Probable/Proved Ore Reserves and Indicated/Measured Mineral Resources. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure is not required to comply with Rule 11.8.3 where a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based upon:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), what specific content must be included about (i) the assumptions used and (ii) the Production Target itself?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target—whether the disclosure is made in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s)—must include both assumption-related content and Production Target-related content in the disclosure. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] For the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, the disclosure must cover all material economic assumptions employed and also include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because the forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all the information that is required to be contained in that Production Target under Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] This combined content expectation applies regardless of whether the Production Target-based forecast is presented against holdings or against material project(s). [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If a Third Party Provider is about to sign a Governing Contract with a Customer, what details have to be in the contract (unless they both agree something else in writing), and when does the Customer need to get that information so they are not bound too early?
gold_answer: The Customer must be given the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer agree otherwise in writing, the Governing Contract must itself contain that information, so providing the contract with the required content is the normal way to meet the pre-binding delivery requirement. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The required contract content includes: who the Third Party Provider is (its name, its ADGM office address/contact details, and its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details); what the Third Party Services are (main characteristics, what customer information/unique identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, how consent is given, when a Third Party Transaction is treated as received, maximum service time, and any usage limits); and what it costs (all charges and, where relevant, exchange rate details including Reference Exchange Rates and how changes apply if agreed). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It also must explain communications (including technical requirements and what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards and corrective measures (including how/when to notify unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and liability/refund conditions), how changes and termination work, and redress options. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even though information can be provided during the period of the Governing Contract, the key timing point is that the Customer must receive it before being bound. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: If an Authorised Person runs Regulated Activities from a branch outside ADGM, what fee do they pay each year and how is the first payment handled, and when could the Regulator add a supplementary fee because of the branch’s country?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has established a branch outside ADGM and uses that branch to conduct Regulated Activities, it must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities it carries on from that branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] The first supervision fee payment is not automatically the full annual amount; instead, the initial supervision fee must be prorated and paid in the manner described in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] Separately, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee (on top of the fees referenced in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2) when the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] In practical terms, the supervision fee is driven by the branch’s Regulated Activities and the proration rule for the initial payment, while the supplementary fee is tied to whether the branch’s jurisdiction has adequate regulator-to-regulator cooperation arrangements in place. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]
source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
target_text: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee equal to 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for those Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch.  The initial supervision fee due shall be prorated and paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a).

question: If a Listed Entity plans an issue of Securities and wants to rely on approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3, what does it have to do when the Related Party Transaction is below the 5% net-assets threshold, and what extra step applies if a series of unapproved transactions with the same Related Party reaches 5% within 12 months?
gold_answer: Where the issue of Securities is being made using approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), the Listed Entity must apply the Related Party Transaction procedures that distinguish between transactions below and at/above the 5% net-assets threshold. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] If the value of the proposed Related Party Transaction is less than 5% of the value of the net assets of the Listed Entity (as stated in its most recent financial reports), the Reporting Entity must, as soon as possible after entering the transaction, notify the Regulator of the relevant terms and explain the basis on which those terms are considered fair and reasonable, supported by written confirmation from an independent third party. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] It must also disclose the Related Party Transaction in accordance with Rule 7.7.1. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] Separately, if there is a series of Related Party Transactions with the same Related Party that have not received Shareholder approval and their cumulative value reaches the 5% threshold in any 12 month period, the Listed Entity must not enter into the last transaction in that series unless it is put to Shareholder approval and receives approval by a majority of the Shareholders in voting. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] This ties back to the securities issuance being undertaken in the Rule 9.5.3 approval context. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4]
source_text: An issue of Securities made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction).

question: When a Listed Entity has only partially adopted the best practice standards in APP 4, what combined annual-reporting disclosures are required regarding (i) reasons and actions for that partial adoption and (ii) the Board/Directors’ opinion on the Corporate Governance framework’s effectiveness, including the additional effectiveness outcome that must be covered under Rule 9.2.10?
gold_answer: Where APP 4 best practice standards are only partially adopted, the annual financial report must explain why full adoption did not occur and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Alongside that adoption narrative, the report must include a statement by Directors giving their opinion on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and with qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] To align with the annual report statement required under Rule 9.2.10, the Board’s statement must also cover whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR, not only promoting compliance with the Principles. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] The supporting material should reflect that the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework and that their application is the central question for the Board in determining how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the applicable requirements. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] Taken together, the partial-adoption explanations and the effectiveness opinion should be coherent and grounded in the entity’s described governance approach. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is updating the market again about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates, when can it avoid repeating the long list of details (like the source and date, reliability, and what work is needed to verify them), and what must it say and do instead?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed disclosure items for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only when the new announcement is clearly tied to an earlier announcement that already included those items. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] In that situation, the later disclosure must refer readers to the earlier compliant disclosure and must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that (a) the earlier information still applies and (b) there is no new material information or data that changes the reliability/interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or affects the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] The later disclosure still needs a prominent and nearby warning statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and it must be at least as prominent and proximate as the earlier required warning. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] That warning must cover the key points that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves after further work. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: If a Listed Entity enters into an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is expressly conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made, how does that approval condition interact with (i) the requirement to obtain holder approval when the 20% formula cap would otherwise be exceeded and (ii) the treatment of such approved issues in calculating “Relevant Issues” for the 12‑month formula?
gold_answer: Where the Listed Entity uses an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on holder approval under Rule 9.7.1, it cannot proceed to issue the Equity Securities unless that approval is obtained, because the condition is a mandatory precondition to issuing under that exception. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] Separately, the Listed Entity must obtain approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities if it would otherwise issue or agree to issue more Equity Securities than permitted by the formula “(20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues.” [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Once approval under Rule 9.7.1 is obtained, the approved issue (or agreement to issue) is treated as excluded from “Relevant Issues,” because Relevant Issues do not include Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In practical terms, the Rule 9.7.1 approval both (i) satisfies the condition required to actually issue under the conditional agreement and (ii) prevents that approved issuance/agreement from counting toward Relevant Issues in the 12‑month calculation, which can affect whether the formula cap would be exceeded. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made.  If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has already put out a Prospectus, what should happen if something important changes or a big error is found after the Prospectus is issued, and how does this connect to the original need to publish a Prospectus?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the Issuer is expected to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for such offers. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] After that Prospectus has been issued, the rules then require an additional step if certain events occur: if at any time there is a significant change, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting something in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer (or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus) must produce a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] That supplementary prospectus has two core content/compliance elements: it must describe the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must comply with the requirements in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The link between the two texts is that the supplementary prospectus obligation only makes sense once the Issuer has already met the initial prospectus publication requirement for the public offer in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] The trigger is explicitly tied to the period after the Prospectus is issued, and it applies whenever the specified kinds of developments occur. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_text:
Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus
If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which—
(a)	provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and
(b)	complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: When preparing the annual report explanation referenced in the SOURCE, how should a Reporting Entity frame that explanation so it aligns with the Regulator’s rulemaking scope in TARGET—specifically regarding Corporate Governance principles and standards (including board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons), fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests—and what long-term management outcome should the explanation demonstrate?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity should use the annual report explanation to show, in a practical and outcomes-focused way, how its real-world Corporate Governance practices meet the outcomes that section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles are intended to achieve, rather than merely describing formal structures. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] In doing so, the explanation should be framed to reflect the areas the Regulator may prescribe by Rules for Corporate Governance: principles and standards applicable to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that may apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions addressing conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The explanation should therefore connect the Reporting Entity’s actual practices to these rule-prescribed governance dimensions and make clear how those practices support an adequate Corporate Governance framework. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The management outcome the explanation should demonstrate is that the framework promotes prudent and sound management in the long-term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.

question: When calculating CET1 Capital deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, how should an Authorised Person determine whether the holding is treated as a “significant investment” (thereby falling under the deduction category for significant investments rather than the category for non-significant investments), and what types of deductions are required to be taken from CET1 Capital in that calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must first classify its holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities by determining whether the holding constitutes a “significant investment,” because the CET1 deduction category differs depending on that classification. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] A holding is treated as a significant investment if any of the specified conditions are met: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is not included in consolidation under Chapter 8 but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] Once classified, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does not have a significant investment, and separately the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does have a significant investment. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In addition, the CET1 deduction calculation includes other specified items such as current-year losses, IFRS-defined goodwill and other intangible assets, and deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: If a Recognised Clearing House can’t get one specific transaction settled, does that automatically mean it failed the Recognition Requirement, and what DSF features does the FSRA still look at under MIR Rule 4.3.3 to judge timely settlement arrangements?
gold_answer: No—being unable to arrange settlement for a particular transaction, on its own, does not mean a Recognised Clearing House is treated as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Even in that situation, the FSRA’s assessment of a DSF under MIR Rule 4.3.3 focuses on whether the DSF has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of transaction parties. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] To make that determination, the FSRA may look at practical elements of the DSF’s design and operations, including its clearing and settlement rules and practices and any arrangements it has with another Person to provide clearing and settlement services. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] The FSRA may also consider how the DSF matches trades and confirms the parties agree on trade details, and (where relevant) how it handles deliveries and payments in the jurisdictions involved. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] In addition, the FSRA can review the DSF’s tools for detecting and dealing with settlement failures by a Member (or participant), its arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not, and its monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, including Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]
target_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

question: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should a firm reconcile the SOURCE requirement to compute an Exposure value using an IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future Exposure with the TARGET SA-CCR requirement to calculate EAD per netting set using alpha, replacement cost (RC), and potential future exposure (PFE)?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value framework in the SOURCE is built from two components: (i) an on-balance sheet amount determined under IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the firm is applying the SA-CCR method described in the TARGET, it must calculate EAD separately for each netting set and determine it using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] To reconcile the two, the firm should treat the TARGET’s PFE term as the structured “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept referenced in the SOURCE, because both are explicitly defined as potential future exposure amounts calculated under App 4 rule references. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] In addition, the TARGET requires RC (replacement cost) to be calculated under its specified rule set and combined with PFE before applying alpha, and this netting-set-by-netting-set EAD calculation provides the SA-CCR-specific way to operationalize the Exposure measurement for derivatives alongside the SOURCE’s IFRS-plus-add-on structure. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, when can its later update about forecast financial information from a Production Target leave out the detailed assumptions and Production Target information, and what did the first Rule 11.9.1 disclosure need to contain so the later update can point back to it?
gold_answer: A later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target can leave out the Rule 11.9.2 information only when it is built on an earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure and includes the required confirmations and any required cautionary statements tied to the basis of the Production Target. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] The earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure that the Mining Reporting Entity points back to must have included the key assumption and Production Target content: all material economic assumptions used, any statement that those economic assumptions are commercially sensitive (if that is the case) plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, and all other material assumptions utilised. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It also must have included the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the later disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must reference that earlier compliant disclosure and state that the material assumptions from the first disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or partly based on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must also include an equally prominent and nearby statement about the forecast financial information matching the relevant statement specified in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d) or Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: For an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money, what must be submitted to the Regulator annually, and what specific statements must the Auditor include in that report as at the date of the Authorised Person's audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] In procuring the production of that Client Money Auditor's Report, the Authorised Person must ensure the Auditor makes specified statements as at the date on which the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The report must cover both quantitative and qualitative matters, including: - The amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14 as at that date. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether, throughout the year, the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls to comply with the relevant provisions of COBS Chapter 14 and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations for preparing the report to the Regulator, and (if applicable) whether there were material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: What does an Authorised Person’s periodic stress test need to cover for securitisations, if it must also check whether the firm can still do securitisation in the future for CRM or liquidity, and take into account stressed market conditions and pipeline deals that might not close?
gold_answer: The periodic stress test needs to be built so it covers the required securitisation perimeter and also the specific stressed-scenario questions the rules call out. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] First, it must be a periodic stress test that relates to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and it must include testing whether the firm will be able in the future to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Second, when running those tests, the firm must look at stressed market conditions and assess the firm wide impact of the securitisation activities and Exposures, including what those stresses mean for other sources of risk (not just the securitisation positions themselves). [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Third, the test scope must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, because the analysis must reflect the risk that pipeline transactions may not be completed in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Putting these together ensures the test covers current and planned securitisation activity, future execution capacity for CRM/liquidity, and the firm-wide consequences under stress. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about where/how the Securities are offered must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For an Issuer that is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF, an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients as part of that MTF-related scenario. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] To fit within the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for this 200-person approach, the offer must be in or from the ADGM, must be directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), and it must occur in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Alongside that capped offer to non-Professional Clients, the Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to Professional Clients, which is described as allowing an unlimited number of Professional Clients under the Professional Client-only circumstance. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] In other words, the Issuer can split the offering into two tranches—one limited to 200 non-Professional Clients under the MTF-linked route, and another directed only at Professional Clients—so long as the MTF/Private Financing Platform condition for the 200-person tranche is satisfied. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating PSIACOMcredit across all applicable Islamic Contracts and must determine the CRW for each contract, how should it treat a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days where the receivable funds arise from a DvP-settled transaction and remain outstanding up to and including the 4th business day after the settlement date, and how does that categorisation feed into the PSIACOMcredit calculation steps?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should treat that not-past-due CR Exposure as falling within the “cash items” asset class, because receivable funds from DvP-settled transactions that are outstanding up to and including the 4th business day after settlement are expressly included in cash items. [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f] In the PSIACOMcredit process, that categorisation matters because the Authorised Person must determine the risk weighting or capital charge appropriate to each contract, which becomes the CRW for that contract, and then use that CRW in the applicable formula to compute PSIACOMcredit for the contract before aggregating across contracts. [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787] Practically, the Authorised Person must (i) identify the Islamic Contracts in scope, (ii) value each underlying investment or asset and apply the required reduction to arrive at “E,” (iii) determine the CRW (informed by the exposure’s asset-class treatment, here cash items), (iv) apply the relevant IFR formula to calculate PSIACOMcredit for each contract, and (v) sum the contract-level PSIACOMcredit amounts to obtain the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person. [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787] This linkage ensures the DvP timing condition (up to the 4th business day) is reflected in the exposure classification used when setting CRW for the PSIACOMcredit computation. [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f]

question: If an Authorised Person is doing Regulated Activities and also putting out Investment Research, who does it need to check for conflicts under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and what extra control requirement applies to the Investment Research itself?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must run a conflicts check that matches Principle 7 in Rule 2.2.7 and, at the same time, ensure it has adequate procedures and controls for the Investment Research it prepares or publishes. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The conflicts check is not limited to obvious issues; it requires taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts that arise or may arise while the Authorised Person is providing any Regulated Activities. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] When doing that identification, the Authorised Person must look for conflicts between (1) the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client, and (2) one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In addition to identifying conflicts, the Authorised Person is expected to take reasonable steps to prevent or manage actual or potential conflicts, and this obligation sits alongside the separate requirement for adequate procedures and controls around Investment Research. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]
source_text: The requirements in this Rule ‎6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_text:
Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2.2.7, taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest between:
(1)	the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees and Clients, or any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control; or
(2)	one Client of the Authorised Person and another Client,
that arises or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities.

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, what specific pre-recognition conditions must it have in place under the requirements that must be complied with before recognition, including any constraints on eligible securities and any custodian-related safeguards?
gold_answer: To recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person may do so only if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with, because compliance with those requirements is a condition for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Before recognition, the Authorised Person must ensure that the legal arrangement for pledging, assigning, or transferring the Collateral gives it a timely right to liquidate or take legal possession upon the Counterparty’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy (or other defined credit events in the transaction documentation), and where applicable also upon such events affecting the custodian holding the Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also take all steps needed under the applicable law to obtain and maintain an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise netting/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must avoid Collateral where the Counterparty’s credit quality and Collateral value are materially positively correlated, and it must treat securities issued by the Counterparty or any Closely Related Counterparty as ineligible. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] Operationally, it must have procedures enabling prompt liquidation while observing legal conditions for declaring default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure segregation from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]
source_text:
Collateral
In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to earlier disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves (rather than presenting new estimates), what Competent Person-related statements must still appear in the subsequent disclosure, and what conditions must be met to rely on the earlier disclosure for the consent and statement requirements?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure that refers to previously disclosed estimates must still include the Competent Person identification statements required for any disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it may rely on the earlier disclosure for the “first-time” consent-and-statement package only if the specific cross-reference and confirmation conditions are met. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] In the subsequent disclosure, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s), disclose whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (and if not, provide the employer’s name), and identify the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] Separately, the prior written consent as to the form and context of how the estimates and supporting information are presented applies only the first time the Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates, provided that any later disclosure referencing those estimates points back to the earlier disclosure that contained the relevant statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The subsequent disclosure must also confirm that the entity is not aware of new information or data that materially affects the earlier disclosure and that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply without material change. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: For a Listed Entity preparing its annual financial report under the annual reporting on compliance section, how should the Directors’ statement about the effectiveness of the Corporate Governance framework be framed so that it also aligns with the annual report statement required under Rule 9.2.10, including the specific outcome reference and the required supporting material?
gold_answer: The Directors should provide an effectiveness statement that simultaneously (i) addresses the Listed Entity annual financial report requirement to opine on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and (ii) satisfies the annual report requirement under Rule 9.2.10 by also stating whether the framework is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] The statement must be made by Directors/Board and must be supported by information and assumptions, and include qualifications where needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] In addition, because the annual financial report must state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 have been adopted, the effectiveness statement should be consistent with (and informed by) that adoption disclosure and any explanation of partial/non-adoption and actions taken to achieve compliance. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Finally, the Board should treat how the Principles are applied as the central focus when determining how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs in line with the applicable requirements, so the supporting information should address application of the Principles in practice. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a Home Regulator has already taken steps about a Passported Fund but the Fund Manager (or its Agent or another Licensed Person promoting it) is still causing serious harm in ADGM, what happens next—first with urgent discussions and then if those talks don’t fix the problem in a reasonable time?
gold_answer: When a Passported Fund situation in ADGM remains materially prejudicial even after measures (if any) taken by the Home Regulator, the Regulator can respond by asking for urgent discussions with the Home Regulator that has supervision and enforcement responsibility for the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] The prejudice that can trigger this includes harm to Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM, or harm to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (the ones referred to in Rule 9.5.2) do not settle the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator is not limited to continued dialogue and may take all appropriate measures needed to protect Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to safeguard the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market.
