(b)	the size of that transaction is equal to or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size, as specified in Rule 3.6.10. In order to determine the relevant minimum qualifying size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover to be calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6.10.
target_text:
Deferred publication thresholds and delays
The table below shows, for each permitted delay for publication and each class of Financial Instrument in terms of average daily turnover (ADT), the minimum qualifying size of transaction that will qualify for that delay in respect of a Financial Instrument of that type.

question: When a Relevant Person conducts business entirely in an NFTF manner and uses eKYC, how should its risk assessment and AML/TFS control framework be structured so that it both mitigates the distinct NFTF/eKYC risks and meets the requirement for regular risk assessments of AML/TFS systems and controls?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person should integrate its NFTF/eKYC-specific risk assessment into its broader AML/TFS systems and controls so that the assessment both identifies concrete mitigation actions for NFTF business (including eKYC) and also tests whether the overall AML/TFS framework remains adequate over time. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] The risk assessment should explicitly address that risks can differ when business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner versus a relationship that mixes face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should set out actions to mitigate those NFTF and eKYC risks. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] In parallel, the Relevant Person must establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to the Relevant Person and its activities, and it must ensure regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of those AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable identification, assessment, monitoring and management of money laundering risk in a comprehensive and proportionate way. [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] To make the NFTF/eKYC assessment actionable within that framework, it should reference risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]
source_text: The risk assessment under Rule ‎6.2.1(c) should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with undertaking NFTF business generally, and the use of eKYC specifically. This is because distinct risks are often likely to arise where business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner, compared to when the business relationship includes a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions. The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: Under what conditions may a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund also perform fund administration for the Fund, and what risk-management considerations must the Fund Manager ensure are addressed in that scenario, taking into account the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians (and, where appointed, prime brokers)?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to carry out fund administration for the Fund only where the Fund’s risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] In that same operating model, the Fund Manager must still ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of the Fund are adequately addressed, and must do so with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and to the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] Practically, this means the Fund Manager should (i) confirm and maintain the separation between risk management and portfolio functions as the condition that enables it to perform administration, and (ii) structure its risk-management approach so it reflects both how the Fund is managed (strategies and investment process) and how key service providers contribute to the Fund’s operation. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] The requirement to address operational risks applies even if the Fund Manager itself is acting as the Fund Administrator, so the Fund Manager must explicitly consider that role alongside Eligible Custodians and any appointed prime brokers when ensuring risks are adequately addressed. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]
source_text: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to perform fund administration for the Fund in circumstances where risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated (Rule 12.3.10).
target_text: Risk management. A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process employed by the Fund Manager and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and where appointed, prime brokers.

question: For a Mining Production Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, how should it satisfy the requirement to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, and what date constraint applies to the MKT Form 11-1 table included in that Summary when it is disclosed (including when the Summary is instead included in the annual report)?
gold_answer: A Mining Production Reporting Entity must ensure that, across its quarterly reporting cycle, it provides the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once in every 12-month period, unless that Summary is instead provided in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether via a quarterly report to meet the 12‑month cadence or via inclusion in the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity’s Summary must contain a table in the format of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the disclosure date of the Summary of Reserves and Resources, meaning the table’s effective date must fall within the month leading up to the Summary’s disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the quarterly report must state when the prior disclosure of this 12‑monthly Summary occurred and when the next such disclosure is expected to occur, so readers can track the timing of the required Summary disclosures. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]
target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.

question: For the purposes of an investigation, how may the Investigator exercise the power to require a person to attend an interview and answer questions, and what additional requirements can be included in the same written notice (including any conditions on time, place, or premises access)?
gold_answer: The Investigator’s power to compel interview attendance is exercised for the purposes of an investigation by requiring a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] In operational terms, the Investigator may implement that power by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The same written notice can also impose additional, distinct requirements that support the investigation, including: producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; providing information; providing assistance; and permitting entry to the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Accordingly, when the Investigator uses the interview power for investigative purposes, the notice can combine the interview obligation with document, information, assistance, and premises-access obligations, each framed with the timing/place parameters or business-hours condition stated for that requirement. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information based on a Production Target, and it’s being shared about either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), what details does it have to include about the assumptions and about the Production Target?
gold_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that comes from a Production Target, it can be presented in relation to either the entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), but the disclosure still has to include specific items about assumptions and the Production Target. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] On assumptions, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, plus any other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity thinks the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] On the Production Target, the disclosure must identify the Production Target that the forecast financial information is based on, and it must include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires to be included with that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] These content requirements apply whichever of the two contexts (holdings or material project(s)) the entity uses for the Production Target-based forecast disclosure. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If the Investigator needs information or documents during an investigation, what are the two ways they can get them, and what kinds of things can a written notice force someone (including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to do?
gold_answer: The passages describe two ways the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents during an investigation: on a compulsory basis (mainly by using its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR) or on a voluntary basis. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] When using the compulsory approach, the Investigator may send a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That notice can require several concrete actions that help the Investigator obtain information and documents, including: attending an interview at a specified time and place and answering questions; producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; and providing information or assistance the Investigator requires. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The notice can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents on those premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] If the Investigator proceeds voluntarily instead, the text indicates the Investigator may obtain the relevant information and/or documents without relying on the compulsory powers. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must it carry out on the PFP Prospect to support adequate, clear, fair and not misleading proposal content, and what platform-facing disclosure about that due diligence must be made available to PFP Clients alongside the published proposal details?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must complete due diligence on the PFP Prospect before publishing the financing proposal, and it must also publish to PFP Clients both the financing proposal details and an explanation of how (and how far) its due diligence is performed. [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] As a precondition to publication, the due diligence must cover at least three areas of information provided by the PFP Prospect: (i) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (ii) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing, and (where relevant) regulatory status; and (iii) the financing proposal itself, so that—based on the PFP Operator’s knowledge—the proposal content is adequate, clear, fair, and not misleading. [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] In parallel with publishing the financing proposal on the platform, the PFP Operator must ensure PFP Clients can access: (a) the details of any financing proposal published on the Private Financing Platform, and (b) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence the PFP Operator undertakes concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to run a simultaneous Exempt Offer, how can it combine the 200-person limit for non-Professional Clients with an additional Exempt Offer category, and which Exempt Offer circumstance is expressly not available for that combined approach?
gold_answer: An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF can structure a simultaneous Exempt Offer by using the specific MTF-related circumstance that permits an offer to be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, and at the same time relying on another Exempt Offer circumstance for a different investor segment. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The 200-person limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In addition, the Issuer may pair that 200-person offer with an Exempt Offer made only to Professional Clients (i.e., an unlimited number of Professional Clients), thereby separating the non-Professional Client cap from the Professional Client tranche. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] However, when using the MTF admission pathway and combining Exempt Offer circumstances in this way, the Issuer is expressly not permitted to rely on the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2), even though other Exempt Offer circumstances may be used. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about the offer channel must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For the “up to 200” route, the offer must fit the circumstance where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the MTF admission context described, an Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients alongside the offer to up to 200 non‑Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client leg is consistent with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When structuring the combined approach for admission to trading on an MTF, the Issuer may rely on one or more Exempt Offer circumstances, but there is a specific carve-out: the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) cannot be used as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is updating estimates because it has new data (a Rule 12.6.1 disclosure) and the update includes material Contingent Resources that it has never disclosed before, what information has to be in the disclosure, including what to add if the Contingent Resources depend on new technology or are Unconventional Petroleum Resources?
gold_answer: It must include all items required for a Rule 12.6.1 update and, at the same time, all items required for first-time disclosure of material Contingent Resources. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] For the update aspect, the disclosure must state the types of permits or licences held relating to the estimates, explain the new data and information, explain how that new data and information changed the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources, and describe any changes or additions to previously disclosed information for Contingent Resources by reference to Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] For the first-time material Contingent Resources aspect, it must also include the permits or licences relevant to the disclosed Contingent Resources, the basis for confirming a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and determining a discovery, and a description covering the estimation method, the key contingencies for Contingent Resources classification, and any further appraisal drilling and evaluation work planned to assess commercial recovery and progress the project. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If the Contingent Resources depend on technology under development, it must explain the technology’s commercial-viability status in the specified categories and ensure Unrecoverable quantities are not included in Contingent Resources. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If they relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, it must add the type(s), land area, number of wells, and specialised extraction technology proposed. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec]

question: If a Relevant Person is about to hire a service provider to do CDD and that work will use an eKYC System, what should the Relevant Person check in the initial assurance assessment, and what must be written down before the hire happens?
gold_answer: Before hiring the service provider, the Relevant Person must carry out an initial assurance assessment to judge whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD, and the Relevant Person must have the service provider’s obligations clearly set out in a binding agreement before the appointment is made. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] Where the arrangement involves an eKYC System and the assurance work is being undertaken for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, the Relevant Person should use the assessment to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent and that it allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] To strengthen how the assessment is performed, the Relevant Person should also consider applying assurance standards guidance from the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard-setting bodies. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Taken together, the pre-appointment steps are: assess suitability of the service provider for CDD, test the eKYC System against reliability/independence and compliance enablement expectations, and document the service provider’s obligations in a binding agreement before appointment. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]
source_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule ‎9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
target_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: If a Reporting Entity needs to appoint an auditor, what does it have to do, and what process does it have to follow, based on section 82 of the FSMR and the Part 15/Rules requirement?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must both appoint an auditor and make that appointment using the specific appointment framework referenced for financial reports. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Section 82 of the FSMR creates the requirement for a Reporting Entity to appoint an auditor, so the entity has a clear duty to make an appointment rather than leaving the role unfilled. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] The financial reports provision adds that the Reporting Entity must have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, so the appointment must be done through that Part 15 and Rules route. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Putting these together, the “what” is appointing an auditor (the obligation), and the “how” is that the appointment must be made in line with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part (the required basis for the appointment). [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] This means a Reporting Entity should treat Part 15 and its Rules as the governing process for fulfilling the section 82 appointment duty. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: If you are working out E for a reverse repurchase agreement, what numbers do you subtract and, when you need the MV of the Securities and the value of Collateral for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, where do you get the method for calculating those values?
gold_answer: To calculate E for a reverse repurchase agreement, you start with the amount paid (or the Collateral given) and then subtract the MV of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] However, you cannot choose any ad hoc approach for those MV and collateral figures when the calculation is being done under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Instead, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral that feed into the reverse repo E formula must be calculated using the CRM provisions in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 specify that those values should be calculated in accordance with that Section 4.13 CRM framework. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Put together, the steps are: (1) identify the amount paid or Collateral given and the Securities received for the reverse repurchase agreement, (2) calculate the MV of the Securities and the value of any Collateral using Section 4.13’s CRM provisions, and (3) plug those results into the E equation by subtracting the MV of the Securities received from the amount paid or Collateral given. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]
source_text: The MV of Securities and the value of Collateral under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 should be calculated in accordance with the CRM provisions set out in Section 4.13.
target_text:
For reverse repurchase agreements:
E = Amount paid or Collateral given   MV of the Securities received.

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and if the Offer is for Units of Funds, where do they find the Prospectus requirements instead of chapter 4 of the Rulebook?
gold_answer: A person making an Offer of a Unit is not subject to the provisions in this Chapter or the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter in relation to that activity. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] Separately, when the Prospectus relates to Units of Funds, the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus requirements—covering content and structure—do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Putting these together for an Offer that involves Units of Funds, you should not look to chapter 4 of the Rulebook for the Prospectus content/structure requirements, because that chapter is expressly stated not to apply to Fund Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the applicable source for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This approach is consistent with the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, reinforcing that chapter 4 is not the governing Prospectus framework for Units of Funds even though the Chapter itself is also stated not to apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]
source_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: If a Fund Manager wants to remove a Trustee and appoint a new one, what paperwork must be sent to the Regulator, and what kinds of links between the Fund Manager and the new Trustee would mean the new Trustee is not independent?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice saying it intends to remove the Trustee, and it must include either (i) a certification that the change will not negatively affect Unitholders’ interests and will not undermine the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and the replacement with another Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The Fund Manager must also provide the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee and confirm that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as replacement Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] Separately, the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager, so the Fund Manager should check that none of the listed relationships exist between it and the proposed replacement Trustee. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] The new Trustee would not be independent if either party holds or votes Shares of the other, they share a common holding company (or ultimate holding company), they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or they have had professional or material business dealings in the last two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]
source_text:
The Regulator may grant approval for the replacement of a Trustee only where it has received:
(a)	a written notice from the Fund Manager of its intention to remove the Trustee and either:
(i)	a certification that the removal of the Trustee will not adversely affect the interests of the Unitholders and the Fund Manager's ability to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR; or
(ii)	a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the Fund Manager's proposal to remove the Trustee and its replacement with another Trustee; and
(b)	the written consent of the person who agrees to be the replacement Trustee, and that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as the replacement Trustee.

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in different jurisdictions, what do they have to do to work out the Countercyclical Capital Buffer and how does that connect to the rule that says they must keep the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must both (1) compute a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital using a jurisdiction-based formula and (2) continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] For the calculation, the Countercyclical Capital Buffer must equal the Authorised Person’s Total Risk Exposure Amount multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that multiplication must be calculated under Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average of the jurisdictional buffer rates must be calculated under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] Separately, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, and that required buffer amount is determined using the calculation approach in Rule 3.18.4. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf] Taken together, the rules mean the Authorised Person cannot treat the buffer as a one-off computation; it must be held continuously in CET1 Capital while being calculated using the specified rule-based methods. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: If you are working out exposure for Derivatives (including written credit protection), what are the pieces you need from the SOURCE (IFRS amount plus add-on) and how does the TARGET say to combine RC and PFE (with alpha) for each netting set?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the SOURCE says the Exposure value is made up of two parts: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS, plus an add-on for potential future Exposure that is calculated using the referenced App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] The TARGET then gives a specific SA-CCR calculation that must be done separately for each netting set, which is important because it sets the unit of calculation (netting set) rather than a single portfolio-wide number. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Under SA-CCR, EAD is computed as EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), where alpha is 1.4, RC is replacement cost calculated under the specified rules, and PFE is the potential future exposure amount calculated under the specified rule. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Linking the two passages, the “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept in the SOURCE aligns with the TARGET’s PFE component, because both are explicitly framed as potential future exposure amounts determined by referenced App 4 rule calculations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Practically, you would identify the IFRS on-balance sheet amount per the SOURCE and then use the TARGET’s netting-set SA-CCR structure (RC and PFE with alpha) to express the exposure measurement in the SA-CCR form. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: When deciding whether to revoke a Recognition Order, how does the Regulator distinguish between using its power to give directions to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements (including directions that may require premises access or suspension of activities) and proceeding to revocation, and what specific circumstances trigger the revocation approach?
gold_answer: The Regulator may use directions to require a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order where a direction is not suitable or the Recognised Body’s position warrants revocation. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] In particular, revocation is typically considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to meet one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also the usual approach where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction given under the Regulator’s direction power, or where (for another reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give such a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] By contrast, where directions are used, the specified steps can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and requiring suspension of the carrying on of any activity for the period stated in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months starting on the day the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, how should the firm determine which collateral-recognition approach is permitted, including the distinction between exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and whether the SFT sits in the Trading Book or Non Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for an SFT only in the circumstances and using the methods specified for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures, and the permitted method depends on both how the exposure is determined and which book the SFT is in. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying the framework set out in Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] In addition, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must choose either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, apply that single chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and avoid mixing the two approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] By contrast, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is restricted to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its economic assumptions are “commercially sensitive” in a Rule 11.9.1 forecast disclosure, what must it still explain, and when might it be hard to justify calling those assumptions sensitive? Also, what must it disclose about the Production Target used for the forecast?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity believes its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must still include the material economic assumptions used for the forecast financial information and provide a statement that it considers them commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also disclose all other material assumptions used in preparing the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] However, the Mining Reporting Entity should be cautious about asserting sensitivity where it is not warranted: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] In addition to assumptions, the disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case.  If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: If a firm’s dealing is only as Matched Principal, but it also has permission for Providing Credit, how do you decide whether it fits Category 2 or instead falls into Category 3A, and what extra Category 2 conditions must you check?
gold_answer: You must treat “only as Matched Principal” dealing as pointing away from Category 2 and toward Category 3A, and then separately verify whether the firm can satisfy the specific Category 2 conditions tied to Providing Credit/Principal dealing and the category exclusions. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] The Category 2 criteria require that the Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Credit and/or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), that the firm’s dealing activities are not limited in scope as described in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i), and that it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] In contrast, where dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, those activities are treated as falling within Category 3A under Rule 1.3.3(1), rather than being determinative for Category 2. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] This means that even if the firm has Providing Credit permission, it cannot rely on “Matched Principal only” dealing to meet the “Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal)” element for Category 2. [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] The practical outcome is that you classify the dealing activity as Category 3A when it is only Matched Principal, and you only classify as Category 2 if the firm independently meets the Category 2 tests (including the scope limitation and category exclusions). [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to rely on the Exempt Offer circumstance that permits an Offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, can the Issuer simultaneously structure the same fundraising as an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, and what limitation applies to which Exempt Offer circumstances may be combined?
gold_answer: Yes. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer that (i) is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and (ii) is also directed to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, provided the Issuer is relying on the relevant Exempt Offer circumstances in combination as permitted. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The “200 Persons” limb corresponds to the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] The “unlimited Professional Clients” limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When combining Exempt Offer circumstances for this MTF admission scenario, the Issuer may rely on one or more of the circumstances within the relevant Exempt Offer rule set, but it cannot use the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: When a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity writes its annual financial report, what does it need to say about adopting the Corporate Governance Principles, and how does that connect to the need to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of compliance?
gold_answer: In its annual financial report, a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies must make specific statements about its Corporate Governance Principles position, and this reporting should be handled with awareness that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities also have to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with those principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] The annual financial report must state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the report must explain why that is the case and describe what actions (if any) have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The report must also include a Directors’ statement on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions and may include qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Preparing these disclosures in the annual financial report helps align the entity’s annual reporting with the separate Rule 9.2.10 compliance-reporting obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When an Authorised Person wants to provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, what must its Credit Risk policy include to rely on the employee-credit-policy carve-out while still meeting the conflicts/approval-process controls for Related Person transactions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat more-favourable credit to a Related Person as permissible if it is delivered under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees and is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] To rely on that approach within its Credit Risk policy framework, the policy must also include adequate conflicts-of-interest procedures for the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] The employee policy must clearly specify the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from, or breach of, the applicable terms, conditions, or procedures so timely and appropriate action can be taken. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Separately, where the policy allows Exposures to Related Persons (on no-more-favourable terms), it must require prior written approval by the Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures (and any write-off) exceeding specified amounts or otherwise posing special risks, and it must exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure refers to earlier estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves and also includes such estimates in the later disclosure, what specific confirmations and cross-references are required, and what Competent Person identification details must be stated in that disclosure?
gold_answer: Where a later disclosure refers to earlier estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the Mining Reporting Entity must reference the earlier disclosure that was compliant with Rule 11.12.1 in order for Rule 11.12.1 to be treated as applying only the first time. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] It must also confirm that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s). [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] Because the subject matter is estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the later disclosure must further confirm that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] Separately, because the later disclosure contains estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (and the rule also covers Exploration Targets and Exploration Results), it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer, and it must identify the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: If a Third Party Transaction wasn’t authorised under Rule 20.7 and it causes an unauthorised Payment Transaction, who does the Third Party Provider have to pay back (and how do you avoid paying the same amount twice), and what is the latest deadline after the Third Party Provider confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
gold_answer: When an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in line with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must make refunds to both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, with an offset to prevent double recovery. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] It must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, but it can subtract (i.e., pay “less”) any amount it has already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution, so the Customer is not effectively reimbursed twice for the same unauthorised amount. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] After the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund promptly and no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This creates a clear latest cut-off tied to the confirmation date, rather than the original execution date. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: If a trader in bond futures buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and then refuses to re-lend them (or only lends to people they think won’t re-lend), how does that connect to the rule about placing orders or doing trades that can mislead the market or keep prices at an abnormal level when it’s not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices?
gold_answer: This bond-futures pattern can fit the rule’s concern where the trader’s transactions or orders are used to influence market conditions in a way that produces a distorted price outcome, and the activity is not for legitimate reasons and not consistent with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In the example, the trader holds a long position in bond futures, acquires a large quantity of the deliverable bonds by buying or borrowing, and then restricts re-lending (either refusing to re-lend or lending only to parties the trader believes will not re-lend to the market). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] The stated purpose is to push the delivery price faced by short-position holders to a materially higher level, allowing the trader to profit on the long position. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] That purpose-and-effect linkage is the “fusion” with the rule: using trading and related actions to secure the price of a Financial Instrument at an abnormal or artificial level is explicitly captured, provided the conduct is otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] Put simply, the example supplies the concrete mechanism (restricting bond availability to raise the delivery price), and the rule supplies the legal characterization test (abnormal/artificial price secured through non-legitimate, non-accepted-market-practice transactions or orders). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If a Listed Entity plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply APP 7 restrictions, or can some APP 7 categories be switched off when it qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test?
gold_answer: The starting point is that a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities must apply the restriction in APP 7, unless the Regulator uses its discretion to require different restrictions. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] But that baseline obligation is narrowed by a specific carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply for certain Listed Entities. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] To decide what to apply, the entity should check whether it meets any of the carve-out conditions while still recognizing that APP 7 is the default restriction framework for Restricted Securities. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The carve-out applies if the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue that the Regulator accepts, or (3) in the Regulator’s opinion has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] This means the entity may still need to apply other APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions the Regulator sets), but the listed categories can be disapplied when the conditions are met. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]
source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Subject to Rule 9.6.2, a Listed Entity which has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, must apply the restriction in APP 7 or such other restrictions as the Regulator, in its discretion, decides.
target_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that:
(1)	qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15;
(2)	has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or
(3)	in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what does it need to do with GEN Rule 5.2.14 (especially the word “Investment”), and which other rule sets does it have to follow for that activity (including what changes if it also provides custody)?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, GEN Rule 5.2.14 applies to that Authorised Person, and the rule must be read so that any mention of “Investment” is understood to mean “Virtual Asset”. [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] This requirement is not standalone: it applies on top of the general requirements that already apply to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets under Rules 17.1–17.6. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] In addition, for the Multilateral Trading Facility activity, the Authorised Person must comply with the requirements in COBS, MIR and GEN as set out in Rules 17.7.2–17.7.6, which is the broader rulebook context that includes GEN Rule 5.2.14. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] If the Authorised Person is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must also comply with Rule 17.8, in addition to the Multilateral Trading Facility requirements and the GEN Rule 5.2.14 reading described above. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]
source_text:
In addition to the general requirements applicable to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets as set out in Rules 17.1 – 17.6, an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in:
(a)	COBS, MIR and GEN, as set out in Rules 17.7.2 – 17.7.6; and
(b)	Rule 17.8 if also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets.
target_text: GEN Rule 5.2.14 shall apply to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and all references to “Investment” shall be read as references to “Virtual Asset”.

question: When applying the 20% cap formula for a Listed Entity’s proposed issue or agreement to issue Equity Securities, how must the entity count Convertible Securities and partly paid Securities when determining the number of Equity Securities for the “Relevant Issues” subtraction, and how does that counting interact with the requirement for approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless it has approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] To apply that formula correctly, the entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue (including those that contribute to “Relevant Issues”) using the specified counting rules, unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] In that calculation, each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up, and each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted amounts then feed into the “Relevant Issues” figure, which is defined as Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, excluding those done with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, the counting method determines the size of the subtraction for Relevant Issues and, in turn, whether the proposed issue exceeds the cap and therefore requires holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Fund Manager runs an ADGM Green Fund, what part of the Fund’s property needs an ongoing and at least annual third-party attestation, and when can the Fund Manager avoid appointing a third party (either by self-attesting for a Qualified Investor Fund or because the assets track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark)?
gold_answer: As a baseline, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but only for a defined slice of the Fund’s holdings. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] Specifically, the requirement is limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] There are two ways the Fund Manager can avoid appointing a third party: (1) if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager chooses to provide the attestation itself, then a third-party appointment is not required because the Fund Manager performs the attestation. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] (2) if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (linked to Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.
