[#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Even when relying on that carve-out, the entity must still ensure the disclosure contains the required Non-Equivalent Estimates content, including a prominent nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not made under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow such disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The disclosure must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used differ from (or match) those in a Mining Reporting Standard; address relevance and reliability; summarise the work and key assumptions/parameters/methods used; provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources and dates; and describe what work is needed to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, including proposed timing and funding source. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] Finally, it must state the classification/reporting standard used and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) attesting that the information provided for items (3) to (9) accurately reflects available data and studies. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items (such as sources/dates, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and the named Competent Person statement) that would otherwise be required when disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, and what statement must still be presented prominently and proximate to the estimates?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed content that would otherwise need to accompany a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation (including items such as sources/dates, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and the named Competent Person statement) only where it previously disclosed the Non-Equivalent Estimates in a manner that complied with the relevant requirements, and the later disclosure meets the specified conditions for relying on that earlier compliant disclosure. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the subsequent disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that the earlier information remains applicable and that there is no new material information or data affecting either the reliability/interpretation of the estimates or the entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on the earlier disclosure for the detailed items, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement addressing the core warning matters required for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked up by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether it falls into Category 1 or Category 3C when its Financial Services Permission includes managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account, and what specific PSIA type and additional determinative authorisations should be checked to avoid misclassification?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should classify itself by identifying which specific Profit Sharing Investment Account (PSIA) permission it holds and then applying the category-specific determinative authorisation tests. If its Financial Services Permission authorises Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, that authorisation is determinative for Category 1 (provided it does not meet the criteria of Category 5). [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] By contrast, Category 3C is tied to authorisation for Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr (and/or certain other listed activities), and also requires that the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] Practically, the firm should: (i) confirm whether the PSIA permission is PSIAu or PSIAr; (ii) check whether it is authorised for Accepting Deposits (which would also be determinative for Category 1); and (iii) if considering Category 3C, verify whether it is authorised for any of the other Category 3C activities (e.g., Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services). [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The classification should follow the determinative authorisation identified for the relevant category rather than other additional Regulated Activities the firm may also be permitted to conduct. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When assessing an Applicant’s audited financial statements for admission, in what situations would the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i), and how does that interact with the three-year audited accounts expectation (including the Regulator’s ability to accept a shorter period)?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity should expect the Regulator to generally require compliance with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) where the Listed Entity being admitted is admitted under the assets eligibility test, has fewer than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed, or is otherwise viewed by the Regulator as needing quarterly cash reports (including where the admission involves a cash-box). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] This expectation links directly to the audited financial statements baseline for an Applicant: the Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts covering three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] In practice, if the Applicant’s audited accounts cover less than three years (whether because only that history exists or because a shorter period is accepted), that shortfall is one of the circumstances in which the Regulator generally requires the Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Separately, even where the audited accounts meet the period requirement, the Regulator may still generally require Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) if the admission is under the assets eligibility test or involves a cash-box, reflecting a perceived need for quarterly cash reporting. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] The audited accounts themselves must also meet the specified consolidation, accounting standards, and audit standards conditions. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider have a written deal saying Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges) does not apply, who is responsible for charges and interest when a Payment Transaction is not executed, is executed badly, or is executed late?
gold_answer: For a Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person, the SOURCE text allows the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider to agree in writing that certain specified Rules do not apply, including Rule 19.21.5 on liability for charges. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Separately, the TARGET text sets out a liability position tied to execution problems: it says the Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges the Payment Service User is responsible for, and any interest the Payment Service User must pay, when those amounts arise because the Payment Service Provider did not execute the Payment Transaction, executed it defectively, or executed it late. [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] To answer “who pays” in your scenario, you must use both passages: the SOURCE establishes that (because the user is not a Natural Person) the parties can contractually switch off Rule 19.21.5, while the TARGET provides the concrete statement that, in non-execution/defective/late execution cases, the Payment Service Provider bears liability to the Payment Service User for the relevant charges and interest consequences. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] In practice, you would confirm whether the written agreement actually disapplies Rule 19.21.5 (as permitted by SOURCE) and then apply the TARGET liability statement to the execution-failure facts described. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]
target_text: A Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider.

question: If a Fund Manager tells its auditor in writing to audit the Fund’s financial statements using IAASB standards, what does the Fund Manager then need to make sure the auditor actually says in the Fund Auditor’s Report (including anything that can be about a Sub-Fund and the annual accounting period)?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s responsibilities span both the engagement step and the content-control step: it must give a written requirement to its auditor to carry out an audit of the Fund’s financial statements under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited statements. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] After that, when arranging for the report to be produced, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements in the Fund Auditor’s Report. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund adopted under FUNDS, and whether the statements give a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The true-and-fair view must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, if applicable, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The Auditor must also state if proper accounting records have not been kept or if the statements do not match records/returns or do not comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether it received all needed information and explanations, address consistency of the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report with the financial statements, and include any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: When putting together the Resolution Pack, what information has to be on the master list of all Client Accounts that the Authorised Person must keep?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack must include the master list (or master lists) of all Client Accounts, and that list must be kept with the specific details required for each account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack requirement applies to an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business and explicitly calls for master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the maintained master list covering those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The master list itself must include, for every Client Account, the account’s name and number and where the account is held (its location). [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It also has to identify the bank and provide the bank’s address and contact details, and it must capture the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] In addition, the list must show whether the account is open or closed and record the opening date or closure date, so the Resolution Pack includes an up-to-date view of each Client Account’s status. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: Where a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears able to do so, what preconditions must the Regulator satisfy (including any consultation requirement and the grounds for being satisfied) before issuing a positive direction to take action?
gold_answer: In the scenario where a Recognised Body has not acted under its Default Rules but appears able to take action, the Regulator may issue a “positive” direction requiring action, but only after meeting additional preconditions. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body concerned. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Following that consultation, the Regulator is prohibited from giving the direction unless it is satisfied—based on the consultation—that at least one specified ground applies. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Those grounds are: (i) that not taking action would create an undue risk to investors or other market participants; or (ii) that the direction is necessary in light of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (iii) that the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c). [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Accordingly, the Regulator’s ability to issue the positive direction in this Default Rules context depends both on the appearance that the Recognised Body could act and on completing consultation and reaching satisfaction on one of the listed grounds. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]
source_text:
Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that:
(a)	failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other participants in the market;
(b)	the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or
(c)	the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c).
target_text: The Regulator may issue a "positive" direction (to take action) where in any case a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body could take action.

question: When an Authorised Person proposes to conduct a Regulated Activity in relation to a product it describes as a “Spot Commodity,” how should it frame its submission so the Regulator can determine whether the product is an Accepted Spot Commodity, including how the product’s defining features (e.g., prompt delivery and not being a Financial Instrument) connect to the Regulator’s assessment factors (e.g., sustainable sourcing standards and market fundamentals)?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should present the product in a way that allows the Regulator to confirm it is a “Spot Commodity” and then assess whether it is an “Accepted Spot Commodity” for the intended Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] First, the submission should explain how the product fits the FSRA’s characteristics of a Spot Commodity, including that it is a good sold for cash with prompt delivery on settlement, and that it is not a future-dated delivery contract beyond the market’s standard delivery period. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] It should also clarify that the product is not a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets (such as Securities or Derivatives) and is not a service or other non-good/intangible item (such as currencies or rights in real estate). [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] Building on that classification, the Authorised Person should provide information relevant to the Regulator’s acceptance assessment, including its responsible and sustainable sourcing requirements and standards (including adherence to internationally recognised certification standards where applicable), and market fundamentals such as market practice, liquidity, participant base, transparency, and fair and orderly operation. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] Finally, it should address any other factors the Regulator may consider in deciding whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person’s proposed Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: If a Payment Service Provider is preparing a Framework Contract and also intends to satisfy the Single Payment Service Contract pre-binding disclosure by supplying a draft Payment Order, which specific information items must be covered in the pre-binding disclosure and which additional Framework Contract items must still be included (particularly around consent procedure and cut-off/time-of-receipt concepts)?
gold_answer: Using a draft Payment Order as the delivery method does not change the minimum content that must be provided before the Payment Service User is bound by the Single Payment Service Contract, and it does not remove the need for the Framework Contract to contain its broader set of mandatory terms. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] For the Single Payment Service Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available, before the Payment Service User is bound, the information/unique identifier the Payment Service User must provide for proper initiation or execution, the maximum execution time, the charges payable (with a breakdown where applicable), and—where applicable—the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied. [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Separately, the Framework Contract must include additional operational and procedural information beyond those pre-binding items, including the form and procedure for giving consent to initiation/execution and for withdrawing consent, as well as the time of receipt of a Payment Order and any cut-off time for processing established by the Payment Service Provider. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The Framework Contract must also include the required charges and exchange-rate disclosures (including, where relevant, the method for determining the relevant date for Reference Exchange Rates). [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: If someone is told they must come to an interview to answer questions, what kind of notice do they get first, and can they refuse to answer because it might incriminate them or reveal a confidential communication when the request is made under the listed sections?
gold_answer: Before the interview happens, the person must be given written notice telling them they are required to attend the interview to answer questions. [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] When the obligation to answer questions (and related obligations to allow inspection/copying, or to give/produce information or a Document) is imposed under sections 201, 203, or 206(1)(a), (b), (c) and (e), the person cannot rely on certain arguments as a valid reason to refuse or fail to comply. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab] Specifically for the interview context, the person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question just because the answer might incriminate them, expose them to a penalty, or disclose a communication made in confidence, with the confidentiality aspect being subject to section 209(6). [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] The same “not a reasonable excuse” approach applies to refusing or failing to permit inspection/copying of information or a Document, or to give/produce (or procure the giving/production of) information or a Document, where the person’s reason is that it might incriminate them or reveal a confidential communication (again subject to section 209(6)). [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: If an Authorised Person is arranging professional indemnity insurance, what should the policy cover (including whose conduct and legal costs), what kind of Insurer should it be with, and what does the Authorised Person have to send or report to the Regulator each year and when the cover changes?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must keep professional indemnity insurance that matches the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and it should do so through a contract placed with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] The insurance contract should be written so it covers claims where the Authorised Person could be liable because of the conduct of the Authorised Person itself and its Employees, and it should also include appropriate cover for legal costs that come from a claim. [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] Beyond buying and keeping the cover, the Authorised Person must provide the Regulator with a copy of the insurance cover at least annually, and that copy must cover the following 12-month period. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] The Authorised Person must also be able to demonstrate that the cover is adequate against the same business risk-profile factors, and it must notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover, including changes in the level of cover and whether the cover is renewed or terminated. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]
source_text: In complying with Rule 6.12.2, an Authorised Person should take out and maintain a contract for professional indemnity insurance (PII) from a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and such contract should include cover in respect of claims for which the Authorised Person may be liable as a result of the conduct of itself and its Employees and appropriate cover in respect of legal costs arising from a claim.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	subject to Rule 6.12A, take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance cover appropriate to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person's business;
(b)	at least annually, provide the Regulator with a copy of the professional indemnity insurance cover in (a) covering the following 12 month period and be able to demonstrate its adequacy in relation to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person’s business; and
(c)	notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover in (a), including the level of cover, its renewal or termination.

question: When a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary between a PFP Client and a PFP Prospect, what combined requirements apply to (i) publishing governance/operational arrangements and (ii) retaining transaction-related documentation, and what is the minimum retention period?
gold_answer: Where a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary, it must address both transparency to PFP Clients via platform publication and documentary retention for a defined period. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] On the publication side, the PFP Operator must ensure information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform, including the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] On the record-retention side, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Read together, this means the PFP Operator should (i) publish the Body Corporate’s governance/operational arrangements for PFP Clients to review and (ii) preserve the related transaction documentation involving that Body Corporate for at least six years, so the intermediary structure described to clients is supported by a retained record of how the intermediary was used in practice. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.

question: If an Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by a Relevant Entity, what facts make that ownership a “significant investment,” and how does that decision change which CET1 deduction bucket the holding goes into?
gold_answer: To place a holding into the correct CET1 deduction bucket, an Authorised Person must decide whether its holding in a Relevant Entity is a “significant investment,” because the CET1 rules distinguish between deductions for holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment and holdings where it does not. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The holding is a significant investment if any one of these conditions applies: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the entity is not consolidated under Chapter 8, it is included in the same IFRS accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] If the holding meets one of those tests, the Authorised Person must treat it as a holding where it has a significant investment and deduct the applicable amount under the significant-investment category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] If none of the tests are met, the holding falls into the non-significant-investment category and the applicable amount must be deducted under that separate category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: Before a Relevant Person appoints a service provider to undertake CDD, how should the Relevant Person structure the required initial assurance assessment so that it also supports the assurance expectations applicable when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, and what documentation must be in place at appointment?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person should design the pre-appointment assurance work so it both (i) evaluates whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD and (ii) aligns with the assurance approach expected when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] In practice, this means the initial assurance assessment conducted before appointment should be scoped to test whether any eKYC System involved is reliable and independent and whether it enables the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator, because those are the assurance outcomes the Relevant Person should seek to establish for Rule 9.3.1A purposes. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] The Relevant Person should also consider applying relevant assurance standards guidance issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other standard-setting bodies as part of how it conducts and benchmarks that assessment. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Separately, as a condition of appointing the service provider, the Relevant Person must ensure the service provider’s obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement, and this documentation must be in place prior to appointment. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752]
source_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule ‎9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
target_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: If a Listed Entity is checking whether it needs holders of Ordinary Securities to approve a new issue because of the 20% limit, how should it count partly paid Securities and Convertible Securities when working out the number of Equity Securities for the calculation, including the “Relevant Issues” part?
gold_answer: To decide whether approval from holders of Ordinary Securities is needed, the Listed Entity must compare the proposed issue (or agreement to issue) against the maximum allowed under the formula: (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues; issuing above that maximum is not permitted without that approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] When determining the number of Equity Securities for this purpose (including the amount that contributes to “Relevant Issues”), the entity must apply the counting approach set for new issues unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Under that approach, a partly paid Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could become if fully paid up, and a Convertible Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could convert into. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted totals are then used when identifying “Relevant Issues,” which covers Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but excludes issues made with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 and issues made under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Using these counting rules ensures the cap test reflects potential dilution in fully paid Ordinary Securities terms. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, what should you check to confirm whether the usual “tell the Third Party Provider without undue delay and within 12 months” rule for redress still applies, given the option to agree in writing on different rules and a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions?
gold_answer: Start from the standard position: the Customer only gets redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction if it informs its Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the execution date, once it becomes aware of the issue. [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] Then confirm whether the Customer is not a Natural Person and whether there is a written agreement between the Customer and the Third Party Provider that changes what applies. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Specifically, for non-Natural Person Customers, the parties may agree in writing that certain listed Rules do not apply, and they may also agree that a different time period applies for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Because the redress entitlement is expressly tied to timely notification, your compliance check should (i) verify the existence and scope of any such written agreement and (ii) determine whether it alters the time period relevant to unauthorised/incorrectly executed transactions, while still ensuring notification is made without undue delay upon awareness. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]
target_text: Subject to Rule 20.10.2, a Customer is only entitled to redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the date of execution, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction.

question: When may deferred publication of transaction information be authorised for a large transaction, and how must the firm determine whether the transaction meets the relevant minimum qualifying size by using the ADT-based thresholds and permitted delays table?
gold_answer: Deferred publication may be authorised only where the trade is between a Member (or, where applicable, an Authorised Person) acting on own account and that firm’s Client, and the transaction size is at or above the relevant minimum qualifying size for the instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] To determine whether the size condition is met, the firm must first classify the Financial Instrument (admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) by its average daily turnover (ADT) calculated under the Rule 3.6.10 methodology, and then apply the table’s ADT band and the chosen permitted publication delay to identify the corresponding minimum qualifying size threshold. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] The table links each permitted delay (e.g., 60 minutes, 180 minutes, until end of trading day, or later trading-day-based delays) to ADT ranges and specifies the minimum qualifying size as either a fixed amount, a percentage of ADT, or a max/min expression depending on the ADT band. [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27] Any authorisation for deferred publication cannot extend beyond the maximum deferral period specified for the relevant class of Financial Instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]
source_text:
Deferred publication of large transactions
The deferred publication of information in respect of transactions may be authorised, for a period no longer than the period specified in Rule ‎3.6.10 for the class of Financial Instrument and transaction concerned, provided the following criteria are satisfied:
(a)	the transaction is between a Member or if applicable, Authorised Person, dealing on own account and a Client of that firm; and
(b)	the size of that transaction is equal to or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size, as specified in Rule 3.6.10. In order to determine the relevant minimum qualifying size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover to be calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6.10.
target_text:

The table below shows, for each permitted delay for publication and each class of Financial Instrument in terms of average daily turnover (ADT), the minimum qualifying size of transaction that will qualify for that delay in respect of a Financial Instrument of that type.
