question: For a Listed Entity’s annual financial report that must report on adoption of the APP 4 best practice standards, how should the report operationalize the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach reflected in Rule 9.2.10, including what must be stated when adoption is partial or not full and what additional Directors’ statement is required?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity’s annual financial report should implement the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach by pairing a clear compliance position against the APP 4 best practice standards with an explanation and governance assessment where full adoption is not achieved. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] Specifically, the report must state whether the Listed Entity has adopted the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the “Corporate Governance Principles”). [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have been adopted only partially, the report must explain why full adoption did not occur (or why adoption was only partial, as relevant) and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In addition to this “explain” component, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] This structure aligns the annual reporting content with the “comply or explain” approach referenced in Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72]
source_text: Rule 9.2.10 reflects the "comply or explain" approach adopted by the Regulator in respect of the Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If an Applicant’s audited accounts don’t cover a full three years (or the Regulator accepts a shorter period), when would the Regulator usually make the Reporting Entity follow Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i), and what other admission situations can trigger that same requirement?
gold_answer: If an Applicant’s audited accounts cover less than three years, that fact aligns with a circumstance in which the Regulator generally requires a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] This matters because the Applicant is expected to have published or filed audited accounts covering a prior period of three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] Where the audited history is shorter than three years (including where a shorter period is accepted), the Regulator’s general approach is to require Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in that scenario. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] The same Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) requirement is also generally triggered when the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, or when the Regulator considers—on other grounds—that quarterly cash reports are needed, including where the admission is of a cash-box. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Separately, regardless of the period length, the audited accounts must satisfy the consolidation requirement and be prepared and audited under standards acceptable to the Regulator. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: If someone places trades or orders that could mislead people about supply/demand/price or push the price to an abnormal/artificial level, what do they need to show about “legitimate reasons” and “Accepted Market Practice” for it to be treated as market practice instead of the kind of Behaviour described?
gold_answer: The described Behaviour focuses on transactions or orders to trade that (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or (b) hold the price at an abnormal or artificial level, when those actions are done other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] Against that framing, the market-practice concept is tied to a person being able to establish that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] So, to have the conduct treated as market practice rather than fitting the “otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity” condition, the person must be able to demonstrate both elements: legitimate reasons and conformity with an Accepted Market Practice. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] This linkage matters because the Behaviour description explicitly uses the absence of legitimate reasons and Accepted Market Practice conformity as part of what characterizes the category, even where the effects involve misleading impressions or abnormal/artificial pricing. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] No additional timing, notification, or record-keeping steps are stated in the provided passages beyond the need to establish the legitimate-reasons/Accepted Market Practice basis. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]
source_text: Market Practice. If a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice (see section 92(4)).
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: How should a PFP Operator align its pre-publication review of a PFP Prospect’s management fitness/propriety and the PFP Prospect’s financial soundness/good standing with the requirement to publish the criteria/methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, and what additional due-diligence-related disclosure must be made available to PFP Clients?
gold_answer: The PFP Operator should ensure that the acceptance criteria and methodology it publishes to PFP Clients are consistent with the specific pre-publication due diligence it is required to perform on a PFP Prospect, and it must also disclose how that due diligence is conducted and where it is limited. [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] Before publishing a financing proposal, the PFP Operator’s due diligence must include reviewing information from the PFP Prospect about: management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers) and the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing, and regulatory status if relevant). [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] Because the platform must also publish the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, those published acceptance criteria should reflect that these management and background checks form part of the operator’s review before a proposal is made available on the platform. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] In addition, the PFP Operator must publish to PFP Clients the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence it undertakes concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform, so clients understand the scope and boundaries of the operator’s review. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure with the key assumptions and the split between reserves/resources (including any Inferred Mineral Resources or Exploration Target parts), when can a later update skip repeating those details, and what warning statements still have to appear next to the Production Target in the update?
gold_answer: A later update about a Production Target may avoid repeating the detailed Rule 11.8.2 content (including the material economic assumptions or the commercially sensitive alternative explanation, other material assumptions, and the required breakdown of what proportion comes from reserves/resources and any Exploration Target) only when it is clearly tied back to an earlier disclosure that already provided that information under Rule 11.8.2. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] For the update to qualify, it must reference the earlier compliant disclosure and include a confirmation that the material assumptions used for the original Production Target still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the update can skip the detailed assumptions and proportions, it still has to carry certain prominent warnings depending on what the Production Target is based on. If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the update must include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement in the required form describing the low geological confidence and uncertainty of achieving the target. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the update must include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement in the required form explaining that the Exploration Target is conceptual and uncertain. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, how should it treat the exposure measure in its credit risk calculation when (i) the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and (ii) the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA (including where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used)?
gold_answer: In this combined scenario, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for the SFT when measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure determined under Rule 4.9.15, but it must also apply the FCCA netting-based exposure measure for credit risk capital purposes and use that measure in place of E in the credit risk calculation. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Specifically, because the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty that are covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, following Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (including the case where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used). [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] After calculating E*, the Authorised Person must substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] In parallel, for the same SFT where eligible financial Collateral has been taken and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15, the effect of that Collateral may be recognised in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.

question: If the Listing Authority checks a complaint and decides the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not covered by the Rule 7.2.2 exemption, what will it ask the Reporting Entity to do, and if it thinks the information should have been Disclosed earlier and sends an ‘aware letter’, when and how are the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s reply usually made public?
gold_answer: When the Listing Authority finishes its enquiry and concludes the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] If the Listing Authority also believes the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action). [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] Where an ‘aware letter’ is issued, the Listing Authority usually Discloses the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response at the same time, but only after the response has been received and reviewed. [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4] The purpose of doing so is to make the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities aware that the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures and to show the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries. [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4]
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 that includes new, previously undisclosed material estimates of Contingent Resources, what specific content must be included to address both (i) the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” impact explanation and (ii) the additional Contingent Resources disclosure elements (including any technology-under-development or Unconventional Petroleum Resources details, if applicable)?
gold_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must prepare a single disclosure that satisfies both the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” update requirements and the specific content required for first-time, material Contingent Resources estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] The disclosure must identify the types of permits or licences held that relate to the estimates (and, for the Contingent Resources component, those relevant to the disclosed Contingent Resources estimates). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] It must explain the new data and information and describe how that new data and information affected the estimates (including Contingent Resources). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] For the previously undisclosed material Contingent Resources, it must also state the basis for confirming a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and the determination of a discovery, and describe the estimation method, the key contingencies supporting Contingent Resources classification, and any further appraisal drilling/evaluation work to progress the project. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If the estimates are contingent on technology under development, it must explain the technology’s demonstrated (or not yet demonstrated) commercial viability status and ensure Unrecoverable quantities are not included as Contingent Resources. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If they relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, it must add the specified Unconventional details (type, land area, number of wells, and specialised extraction technology). [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] Finally, it must include any changes or additions to previously disclosed information for Contingent Resources as referenced in Rule 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target after having already disclosed under Rule 11.9.1, under what conditions may it omit the assumption and Production Target information otherwise required in the initial Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what specific content must have been included in that earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure for the cross-reference to be valid?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the Rule 11.9.2 information in a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the subsequent disclosure is explicitly anchored to an earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure that itself contained the required assumption and Production Target content, and the subsequent disclosure includes the specified confirmations and warnings. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] For the earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure to be a valid reference point, it must have included all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, any commercially sensitive statement (if applicable) together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions utilised, as well as the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the subsequent disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must (i) reference that earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) confirm that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Additionally, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the subsequent disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the forecast financial information corresponding to the relevant statement specified in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d) or Rule 11.8.3(7)(b), respectively. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), under what conditions may a subsequent disclosure omit the information otherwise required by Rule 11.9.2, and what additional statements are required in the two specified Production Target scenarios?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the Rule 11.9.2 information in a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target (including where that forecast financial information is disclosed in relation to the entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s)) only if the entity has already made a compliant earlier disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 and the subsequent disclosure satisfies the specified conditions. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] To rely on this omission, the subsequent disclosure must: (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2; and (ii) confirm that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure (on which the forecast financial information is based) still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] In addition, the subsequent disclosure must include extra, prominence-and-proximity statements in these cases: - If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the forecast financial information matching the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] - If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the forecast financial information matching the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If an Authorised Person has both SE Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps does it follow to work out the risk-weighted amounts for each type, and how are the two sets of results added together?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate risk-weighted Exposure amounts separately for SE Exposures and for Early Amortisation Exposures, and then add the totals together as part of the overall securitisation-related RWA calculation. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For SE Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value using the Section 4.9 methodology while recognising any applicable CRM, allocate a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then compute RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight that corresponds to that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For Early Amortisation Exposures, it must measure each Exposure value (EAE) using the same Section 4.9 methodology and CRM recognition, and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] The key difference is that, for Early Amortisation Exposures, CRW is taken from the underlying Exposure type as though the Exposure had not been securitised, rather than being derived from a Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] After calculating each set, it must sum the RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures and add that sum to the RWA(SE) amounts calculated for its SE Exposures (excluding any SE Exposures required to be deducted from Capital Resources). [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for Early Amortisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must:
(a)	calculate the value of the Exposure (EAE) for each of its Early Amortisation Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM;
(b)	calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW
where:
(i)	"RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure;
(ii)	"EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and
(iii)	"CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and
(c)	add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, how should the Regulator determine whether it must permit and accompany the inspection versus when it may refuse to cooperate, particularly where enforcement action or judicial proceedings exist for the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s default position, when it receives a Host Regulator request to carry out an on-site inspection connected to a Passported Fund, is to allow the inspection to proceed and to accompany the Host Regulator during the on-site visit. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] However, the Regulator may decline to act on a Host Regulator’s cooperation request for an inspection if specific parallel actions already exist concerning the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] In practice, the Regulator should (i) confirm that the request is for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the trigger for the permit-and-accompany approach; and then (ii) assess whether either refusal circumstance applies. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The refusal circumstances are limited to cases where the Regulator has already started or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been started or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If neither of those circumstances applies, the Regulator should permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]
source_text: Where the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator shall, subject to Rule 9.3.2, permit such inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection.
target_text:
The Regulator may refuse to act on a request by a Host Regulator for cooperation in relation to an inspection in the following circumstances:
(a)	the Regulator has already commenced, or concluded, enforcement action in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons; or
(b)	judicial proceedings have already been initiated, or concluded, in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons.

question: Where the parties have agreed to disapply the individual Payment Transaction information requirements for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, what alternative transaction information must the Payment Service Provider provide or make available, and what is the fallback requirement when the instrument is used anonymously—particularly in light of the fact that Low-Value Payment Instruments under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used for Stored Value?
gold_answer: If, for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the parties agree that the usual information for individual Payment Transactions (as specified in Rules 19.2.13 and 19.2.14) will not apply, the Payment Service Provider must follow the alternative information approach set out for such instruments. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Under that alternative approach, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference that enables the Payment Service User to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction, and any charges payable for that Payment Transaction. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] If there are several Payment Transactions of the same kind made to the same Payee, the Payment Service Provider must instead provide or make available information about the total amount of those Payment Transactions and any charges for them. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Where the Payment Instrument is used anonymously, or the Payment Service Provider is not technically able to provide or make available the information described above, the Payment Service Provider must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This fallback is especially relevant because Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used in relation to Stored Value, making verification of stored Money a necessary substitute when transaction-level reporting cannot be delivered. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]
source_text: Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 encompass those used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is re-using earlier estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves in a later announcement, what must it say about the Competent Person, and what extra cross-reference and “no material change” confirmation does it need so it can rely on the earlier consent and statement?
gold_answer: In a later announcement that refers to earlier estimates, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must still include the required Competent Person statements for a disclosure that contains Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it can treat the consent-and-statement requirement as already satisfied only if it links back to the earlier disclosure and makes the required confirmations. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] The announcement must identify the named Competent Person(s) whose prepared information and supporting documentation the disclosure is based on and which it fairly represents, state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (or otherwise give the employer’s name), and name the professional organisation each Competent Person belongs to. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] For the consent aspect, the prior written consent about the form and context of presenting the estimates and supporting information is only required the first time the entity discloses original or updated estimates, as long as the later announcement that mentions those estimates points readers to the earlier disclosure that included the statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The later announcement must also confirm there is no new information or data that materially affects what was in the earlier disclosure and that the key assumptions and technical parameters behind the estimates have not materially changed. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: What does a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity have to put in its quarterly report (including what to say if there were no activities and what to cover about controlled entities), and how soon after the quarter ends does it have to disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity’s quarterly report has two linked requirements: it must include specific Petroleum-related information for the quarter (with a consolidated scope where relevant), and it must be disclosed within a set time after the quarter ends. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] On content, the report is for each quarter of the financial year and must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, using a consolidated basis if applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must describe activities relating to Petroleum Exploration (or clearly state there were no Exploration activities) and production and development (or state there were no mining production and development activities). [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It also must summarize expenditure for Exploration and for production and development, list Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements), and identify Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including those beneficial interests) with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] Separately, the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months unless included in the annual report, and it must indicate when the prior and next such disclosures were and are due. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: If an Authorised Person can withdraw from an Underwriting commitment using an irrevocable right that lasts for a set period, when does the commitment start, and how does that interact with the usual rule about signing the agreement or setting the price and allocation for the issue of Securities?
gold_answer: When the Authorised Person has an irrevocable right (at its discretion) to withdraw from an Underwriting commitment and that right can be used only within a specified period, the commitment is treated as starting when the withdrawal right period ends (i.e., when the right expires). [#TGT:d9495a44-ecf5-4db3-bd33-e8da8d5b4a76] Outside that specific situation (or after the right has expired), the Authorised Person must treat the initial commitment to underwrite an issue of Securities—subject to any right set out in Rule 5.10.6—as beginning from whichever happens first: signing an underwriting agreement with the Issuer of Securities, or the point when the price and allocation of the issue are set. [#SRC:5e3c35e9-6a09-4cca-aa79-0467e4867446] So the practical sequence is: check whether the underwriting arrangement includes the described irrevocable withdrawal right and note its expiry date; if it does, use that expiry as the start of the commitment. [#TGT:d9495a44-ecf5-4db3-bd33-e8da8d5b4a76] If it does not (or once it has expired), determine the start by comparing the signing time against the time price and allocation are set, and choose the earlier of those two. [#SRC:5e3c35e9-6a09-4cca-aa79-0467e4867446]
source_text:
An Authorised Person must regard a commitment to underwrite an issue of Securities, subject to any right set out in Rule 5.10.6, as the initial commitment to underwrite from the earlier of:
(a)	the time the Authorised Person signs an agreement with the Issuer of Securities to underwrite those Securities; or
(b)	the time the price and allocation of the issue are set.
target_text: If an Authorised Person has at its discretion an irrevocable right to withdraw from an Underwriting commitment, exercisable within a certain period, the commitment commences when that right expires.

question: In the annual report explanation mentioned in the SOURCE, what should a Reporting Entity say about its real governance practices so it covers the kinds of Rules the Regulator can set in TARGET (board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons, fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests), and what overall long-term goal should it show?
gold_answer: In the annual report explanation, a Reporting Entity should focus on explaining how its day-to-day Corporate Governance practices actually deliver the outcomes expected under section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, rather than treating the explanation as a purely formal statement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] To make that explanation complete, it should be organized in a way that maps to the areas the Regulator may set by Rules for Corporate Governance: the principles and standards that apply to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that can apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements about fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions that deal with conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] This linkage helps show how the Reporting Entity’s actual practices are intended to achieve compliance with the outcomes behind the governance framework requirement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The overall goal the explanation should demonstrate is that the governance framework supports prudent and sound management over the long term, in the interest of both the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is preparing its Resolution Pack, what specific Third Party Agent acknowledgement record must be included if the firm passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, and what minimum content must that acknowledgement cover?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgement from that Third Party Agent, and the relevant acknowledgement record must be included in the Resolution Pack as part of the required records for Client Investments involving a Third Party Agent. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The acknowledgement must, at a minimum, address operational and safeguarding points, including: the account title must clearly distinguish the account from any account holding Investments belonging to the Authorised Person and be in the form the Authorised Person requests; Client Investment credits/withdrawals must follow the Authorised Person’s instructions; and Client Investments must be held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] It must also set out arrangements for recording/registering Client Investments and handling dividends/entitlements/interest and instructions, require delivery of statements to the Authorised Person (including frequency) detailing Client Investments deposited, and confirm that Investments in the account are held by the Authorised Person as agent with restrictions on combining accounts or asserting charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims against those Investments for sums owed on other accounts. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] Finally, the acknowledgement must state the extent of the Third Party Agent’s liability in the event of default, and that written acknowledgement record is part of the Resolution Pack’s Third Party Agent acknowledgement materials for Client Investments. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: When an Authorised Person takes out and maintains professional indemnity insurance cover that is appropriate to its nature, size, complexity and risk profile, what specific features should the insurance contract include regarding the Insurer and the scope of claims and legal costs, and how do the annual submission and notification duties to the Regulator apply to that cover?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must maintain professional indemnity insurance that fits the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and that same cover should be structured as a contract placed with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and drafted to address the Authorised Person’s potential liabilities and related legal costs. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In practical terms, the contract should include cover for claims where the Authorised Person may be liable due to the conduct of itself and its Employees, and it should also provide appropriate cover for legal costs that arise from a claim. [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In addition to maintaining the cover, the Authorised Person must, at least once each year, give the Regulator a copy of the insurance cover for the next 12 months and be able to show that the cover is adequate against the same nature/size/complexity/risk-profile benchmark. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] The Authorised Person must also notify the Regulator of any material changes to that cover, including changes to the level of cover and events such as renewal or termination. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]
source_text: In complying with Rule 6.12.2, an Authorised Person should take out and maintain a contract for professional indemnity insurance (PII) from a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and such contract should include cover in respect of claims for which the Authorised Person may be liable as a result of the conduct of itself and its Employees and appropriate cover in respect of legal costs arising from a claim.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	subject to Rule 6.12A, take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance cover appropriate to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person's business;
(b)	at least annually, provide the Regulator with a copy of the professional indemnity insurance cover in (a) covering the following 12 month period and be able to demonstrate its adequacy in relation to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person’s business; and
(c)	notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover in (a), including the level of cover, its renewal or termination.

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the MKT Form 12-1 table and what is the relevant “as of” date constraint, and how does this change if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity generally must include, within its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table using the MKT Form 12-1 format, and that table must be prepared “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] However, if the Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1, which is the rule that imposes the MKT Form 12-1 table requirement and its timing condition. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] In practical terms, the compliance outcome depends on whether the entity falls into that SEC annual filing category: if it does not, it must include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “as of” date is within the one-month window before disclosure; if it does, the entity is exempt from the Rule 12.14.1 obligation and therefore does not have to meet that table-inclusion requirement or its associated “as of” date constraint under that rule. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1]
source_text: Subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.
target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity that is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1.

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is liable to pay compensation for loss suffered by an acquirer of Securities due to an untrue or misleading statement, or a missing material matter required to be included, what specific showings can that person rely on to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps that must be taken before the Securities are acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can face an obligation to pay compensation to someone who acquired the relevant Securities and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can establish one of the specified defenses tied to the accuracy of the Prospectus, the reasonableness of their diligence, or timely corrective action. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] To avoid civil liability in this compensation context, the person must be able to show at least one of the following: (i) the relevant statement was true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive) or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; (ii) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or (iii) before any person acquired the Securities in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to ensure a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If the Regulator is thinking about using Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support or fully carry out a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action (and section 27 might require ex-ante judicial approval), what are the reasons it can still say no to recognising the Foreign Resolution Action, in full or in part?
gold_answer: Even if the Regulator’s plan would be to support or fully implement a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action by using one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (with any applicable ex-ante judicial approval requirement under section 27), it can still refuse to recognise the underlying Foreign Resolution Action, either entirely or only for certain elements. [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] The refusal decision is available where the Regulator is satisfied that one or more listed grounds exist. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] These grounds include an adverse impact on financial stability in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] They also include situations where the Resolution Conditions are not met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in relation to the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5), or where taking Resolution Action under section 78(5) for an ADGM Branch is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Another basis is unequal treatment: if creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not receive the same treatment and similar legal rights as creditors (including depositors) located or payable in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, merely because they are in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse if recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the firm align the contents of its Resolution Pack with its broader obligation to maintain records for at least six years, specifically for Client classification and Client agreements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business should treat the Resolution Pack as a defined subset of its wider recordkeeping population and ensure that the Client classification and Client agreement materials that must appear in the Resolution Pack are also maintained within the firm’s general records for at least six years. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] In practice, this means the Resolution Pack must include the records tied to Client classification and Client agreements identified for inclusion, and those same categories must be retained as part of the firm’s sufficient records maintained for the minimum six-year period. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Specifically, the Resolution Pack must contain the records of Client classification and Client agreements referenced for Investment Business, and the firm’s general recordkeeping must include documents regarding Client classification under Chapter 2 and a record of each Client Agreement (including later amendments agreed with the Client). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Operationally, the firm should ensure its filing and retention approach allows the Resolution Pack copies (or pointers to them) to be preserved for the full six years as part of the sufficient records maintained for each activity and function. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 that included the required material assumptions and proportion breakdown for a Production Target, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit that detailed Rule 11.8.2 information, and what additional proximate statements are still required if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed information that would otherwise be required (such as the material economic and other assumptions and the proportion breakdown across reserves/resources/Exploration Target) only if it is framed as a follow-on to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that itself contained those elements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with the detailed requirements, and (ii) expressly confirm that the material assumptions used for the Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, the later disclosure must still include specific, prominent cautionary statements in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, it must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement in the form required for that scenario (the statement addressing low geological confidence and uncertainty). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must likewise include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement in the form required for that scenario (the statement noting the conceptual nature and uncertainty). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: For an Issuer conducting an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), how should the Issuer reconcile the requirement that the Product Summary Note carry a prominent front-page disclaimer with the general prohibition on including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in, or in respect of, the Product Summary Note?
gold_answer: In an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer is required to include a specific prominent disclaimer on the front of the Product Summary Note, in bold, using the disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] At the same time, Issuers are generally required to refrain from including disclaimers relating to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or disclaimers made in respect of the Product Summary Note. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] Read together, the Issuer should treat the front-page disclaimer mandated for the Exempt Offer Product Summary Note as the only disclaimer content that is affirmatively required, and avoid adding any other disclaimer language that would operate as a disclaimer “in relation to” the information in the Product Summary Note or “in respect of” the Product Summary Note. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] This approach aligns with the Product Summary Note content controls that it must be fair and balanced, not false or misleading, and must not omit information in a way that makes any part false or misleading, which would be undermined by additional disclaimer-style qualifications. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2]
source_text: Subject to Rule 4.3.5, Issuers shall refrain from including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or in respect of the Product Summary Note.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is putting forecast financial information in its disclosure and that forecast comes from a Production Target, what must it say about its assumptions and the Production Target, and how does that fit with the FSRA’s expectation that the disclosure should be fair and balanced compared with the separate report that is attached as an annexure?
gold_answer: The disclosure needs to include a complete set of required assumption and Production Target information for the forecast, and it should be presented in a way that is fair and balanced when compared with the attached separate report, without trying to restate everything in that report. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] For the forecast financial information, the Mining Reporting Entity must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast and also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target that the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must include all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, where the disclosure includes information that comes from the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (which must be attached as an annexure), the information in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of that report; however, the FSRA does not expect a full summary, only the material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report that is not already in the body of the disclosure. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1, the information included in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of the information contained in the separate report prepared in accordance with Rule 11.6.2 (which must be included as an annexure to the disclosure).  In complying with this obligation, the FSRA does not expect a Mining Reporting Entity to prepare a summary of all the information contained in the separate report.  Instead, it is expected that that only information which is material to understanding the estimates of Mineral Resources contained in the separate report, that is not otherwise included in the body of the disclosure, be included.

question: Where a contravention is committed by one person, how does liability attach to another person who is Knowingly Concerned, and how do the consequences differ when the contravention is of FSMR or Rules versus a contravention of these Regulations?
gold_answer: If a contravention is committed by one person and another person is Knowingly Concerned in that contravention, both texts treat the involvement as a basis for liability for both individuals, but they describe the legal framing slightly differently depending on the instrument. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] For contraventions of FSMR or Rules, the SOURCE explains that when one person is Knowingly Concerned in another person’s contravention, section 220 of FSMR provides that both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] For contraventions of these Regulations, the TARGET states that the person who is Knowingly Concerned, as well as the person who committed the underlying contravention, commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] In practical compliance terms, the shared trigger is the “Knowingly Concerned” involvement in another’s contravention, while the linkage across the two passages is that the SOURCE ties liability to section 220 of FSMR for FSMR/Rules contraventions, whereas the TARGET expressly describes exposure to being proceeded against for contraventions of these Regulations. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441]
source_text: Involvement in contravention. If a person is Knowingly Concerned in a contravention of FSMR or Rules committed by another person then, under section 220 of FSMR, both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention.
target_text:
General Provisions. Involvement in contraventions
If a person is Knowingly Concerned in a contravention of these Regulations committed by another person, the aforementioned person as well as the other person commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.

question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person as a sum of component RWAs, how should the Authorised Person delineate what is included in the RWA calculation for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures) versus what is carved out because it is treated as securitisation or Trading Book exposure, including any Traditional Securitisation risk-transference recognition condition?
gold_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must aggregate three distinct RWA components: (i) RWA for all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (ii) RWA for all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (iii) RWA for Counterparty Risk Exposures, each computed under the specified rule sets for those components. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposure component specifically, the Authorised Person must include both on-balance sheet assets and off-balance sheet items in the CR Exposure RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] However, to keep the CR Exposure component distinct from the other Credit RWA components, the Authorised Person must exclude from CR Exposure RWA: (a) any SE Exposure (which instead belongs in the securitisation RWA component of Credit RWA), (b) any securitised Exposure that qualifies for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation under Section 4.14, and (c) any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] This delineation ensures the CR Exposure RWA is calculated on the intended population while the excluded items are addressed through the separate securitisation and other relevant RWA calculations that together form Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]
source_text:
The Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is the sum of:
(a)	its risk weighted assets (RWA) for all its Credit Risk Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "CR Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rules 4.8.2 and 4.8.3;
(b)	its RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "SE Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.4 and Section 4.14; and
(c)	its RWA for its Counterparty Risk Exposures as calculated in accordance with Sections A4.6 to A4.8.
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures). An Authorised Person must include in its calculation of RWA for CR Exposures:
(a)	any on balance sheet asset; and
(b)	any off balance sheet item; but excluding:
(c)	any SE Exposure;
(d)	any securitised Exposure that meets the requirements for the recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation set out in Section 4.14; and
(e)	any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1.

[#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] These conditions operate against the baseline that a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure otherwise must include specified assumptions and other prescribed elements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
